Hence, the governor of Ba County claimed that Sanhuang Pills could treat thirst. In my own experience, after several years without improvement, I removed (stone salt) and nitrate, then added one pound of Coptis to create a large potion, brewing it vigorously for five to seven boils, allowing it to cool, and drinking it in hundreds of sips over several days. Alternately, I used Gui Ling Gan Lu Powder, Bai Hu Decoction, fresh lotus stem juice, light bamboo juice, and raw Rehmannia juice in a staggered manner, producing a large quantity to replace drinking water, and soon achieved recovery. Therefore, for the symptom of thirst, with balanced treatment without excessive purging, it results in slight moisture. A slight moistening ultimately cannot quell the heat rising; if purging is conducted without balance, it leads to continual drinking and dissipation, never truly nourishing the dryness of the diaphragm. Purging, balancing, and not diminishing flavors, without abstaining from desires or regulating emotions—if the illness recurs after recovery, if one can address these three aspects, thirst will not be a major concern.[44p]
    Furthermore, the "Ling Shu" states that a slippery heart pulse indicates good thirst; it also says that a slippery pulse signifies predominant Yang energy. It mentions that when the heart pulse is faint, it signifies consumption, and that fragile heart pulses in the five organs likewise indicate consumption. It describes those with consumption as having thin skin yet firm flesh, tall and upright, with a strong heart. Those who are strong often have anger; when anger arises, Qi reverses upward, accumulating in the chest, and the blood and Qi flow back to the skin, filling the muscles, causing the pulse to stagnate, thus transforming into heat. This heat then consumes the skin, resulting in consumption. It also states that if all five organs are soft and weak, they are predisposed to consumption. Softness and weakness must coexist with strength; strength often leads to anger, and softness easily gets injured. From this, I realized that those with reversed Qi are not only suffering from consumption. If there is cold on the outside, it may lead to boils, shortness of breath, mania, obstruction in the chest, lung consumption, or water retention; if heat invades the organs, it can cause shock, nosebleeds, consumption of the diaphragm, frailty, and abdominal death; if it affects the bowels, it may lead to urinary retention, blood in urine, mouth ulcers, abdominal tension, food issues, throat obstruction, nasal congestion, nosebleeds, or blindness. These twenty-one conditions are all discussed in the theory of Qi counterflow. The text states: All upward counterflows pertain to fire. With just one sentence, an astute reader can seek understanding from it.
    East Garden's "Ten Books" by Li Gao, Yuan Dynasty.[45p]
    Discussion on Thirst

    The distinctions of Yin and Yang state that "the two Yangs converging is called 'thirst.'" The Treatise on the Essentials of Pulse states: "dampness becomes thirst." The two Yangs refer to Yangming. The Hand Yangming (large intestine) governs fluid ailments; when dampness (thirst) occurs, the eyes turn yellow and the mouth becomes dry, indicating insufficient fluids. The Foot Yangming (stomach) governs blood; when heat arises, it causes a thirst for food and a craving for snacks, indicative of blood deficiency due to latent fire. Convergence signifies insufficient bodily fluids that are stagnant and not nourishing, leading to conditions of dryness and heat. This arises from consuming excessively sweet and rich food, causing qi to overflow upward and transform into thirst; such conditions are treated with medicinal herbs like orchid to eliminate stale qi. One must avoid sticky, rich, fragrant food and mineral medicines, as their essence is harsh and can exacerbate dryness and heat.

    A speaker from Yue states: "When evils reside in the six yang organs, the Yang pulse becomes disharmonious; if the Yang pulse is disharmonious, qi will accumulate, leading to an excess of Yang, and if Yang is too excessive, Yin energy cannot nourish, resulting in the thinning and depletion of skin and muscles." The Classics say: "In treating consumption, fatigue, partial paralysis, atrophy, fullness of qi, and rebellious movement in the body, the wealthy who indulge in rich foods suffer these ailments."

    Qibo states: "When the pulse is full, long-lasting illnesses can be treated; when the pulse is thin and small, lasting illnesses are difficult to treat." The conditions are then classified into three types of thirst.

    The first type, known as "upper thirst," manifests as a red and cracked tongue with great thirst and a desire to drink. The Reverse Regulation Theory states that heat moves from the heart to the lungs, resulting in "diaphragmatic thirst," which can be treated with Baihu Decoction augmented with ginseng.

    The second type, "middle thirst," involves good appetite but thinness, spontaneous sweating, constipation, and frequent urination. Shuhe states: "Dry mouth with a desire for more water, despite eating plenty, indicates a deficiency type of thirst."[46p]
    To regulate the stomach, use the Shenqi Decoction and Sanyuan Pill. In cases of lower consumption, there is restlessness with a thirst for water, dry ears, and urination resembling grease. Shuhe states: "When there is extreme restlessness, water is easily depleted, indicating kidney consumption." Treat it with the Six-Flavor Rehmannia Pill. The Comprehensive Directory mentions: "If there are the signs of brain abscess and back sores in those able to eat, it is a dire indication; if unable to eat, it points to abdominal fullness and bloating, both signs of untreatability." The ancient elder Jiegu differentiated treatments: those who can eat but are thirsty should take the White Tiger Decoction with Ginseng; those who cannot eat but are thirsty should take the Qian Family Bai Zhu Powder with an increased dose of Kudzu root. Once the upper and middle levels are balanced, there will be no more lower consumption. Previous physicians had sound intentions in their prescriptions! Some ask: "What are the signs of abscesses and sores in cases of upper consumption?" This is due to the fire pathogen overpowering. The sores are very painful but do not rupture, sometimes with blood-like water. The classic states: "If it has a form but no pain, it belongs to the Yang category." Attack the Yang urgently, while avoiding the Yin; treatment should focus on the lower regions. When vital energy is strong, there is life; when it is lost, there is death. What is the cause of the fullness in the abdomen for those who have consumed? It is treating cold with heat; even the practitioners cannot abandon established methods in favor of new ones. However, organs have varying distances: the heart and lungs are close, hence should be administered in smaller amounts, while the kidney and liver are farther apart and should receive larger doses, each appropriately considering their conditions. Whether one overdoses or underdoses leads to a situation lacking errors in judgment. For high and middle consumption, if treated too abruptly, the disease may pass quickly, leading to lasting abdominal fullness, which precisely indicates the upper heat has not been resolved while the middle cold has resurfaced. This is not the fault of the medicine but rather a failure to appropriately gauge the urgency of the treatments. Therefore, more attention should be given to the prescribing methods.[47p]
    Differentiation of Internal and External Injuries

    When the external evil of wind and cold affects the body for three days, there is a loss of appetite and reduction of fluids, leading to thirst as the pathogenic qi penetrates inward. In contrast, individuals who suffer internal injuries from imbalanced diet or prolonged labor and illness will not feel thirsty, as the pathogenic qi remains excess within the blood vessels. Initially, those who have been overworked, and whose diet has been irregular, will definitely experience thirst if the damage is severe; this is due to the heart fire blazing upward, attacking the lung metal, hence the thirst.

    It is important to discern this. Even if there is a desire to drink cold water, it should be given slowly in small amounts, without yielding to the urge to drink excessively. Too much water can excessively drain the stomach qi, resulting in mild distension or severe transmission of various diseases. The person will inevitably experience recurring disturbances, unrest in the pulse, and increased severity at night, making it difficult to find relief in sleep—this cannot be overlooked.

    Therapeutic Methods
    If there is fever, aversion to heat, and thirst with red eyes, it indicates an internal disease. The hand taiyin (lung) is deficient and cannot regulate the yang qi. One should use ingredients such as wolfberries, fresh rehmannia, and cooked rehmannia as the main treatment. If the pulse is surging and large, and especially if it results in vomiting blood, it indicates a significant condition.

    For thirst in the upper jiao with spontaneous urination, white tiger decoction should be used.[48p]
    In the middle jiao, if thirst is present and urination and defecation are not smooth, the prescription is the Tonic for Regulating the Stomach and Invigorating Qi. In the lower jiao, if there is thirst, red and scanty urine, and difficult bowel movements, the prescription is the Tonic for Greatly Purging Qi. For thirst arising from the six meridians, each should be treated according to its respective meridian's medicine.

    For those with exterior heat, an aversion to heat, and thirst, the prescription is the White Tiger Decoction.

    Danxi’s Heart Method (Yuan Dynasty, Zhu Zhenheng)

    Treatment of Diabetes

    For diabetes, focus on nourishing the lungs, lowering fire, and generating blood, addressing it in three stages: upper, middle, and lower. All three types of diabetes must avoid the use of Pinellia, and those with blood deficiency should also refrain from its use. Those experiencing dry mouth, throat pain, intestinal dryness, or difficult bowel movements should not use it either, and those with excessive sweating should avoid it. If absolutely necessary, ginger can be employed as a controlling agent. If diabetes presents with diarrhea, first use a powdered mix of Atractylodes and White Peony prepared by frying, then follow it with juices and syrups from previous medications. Additionally, Trichosanthes powder is a superb remedy for diabetes.

    In cases of internal injury that leave persistent dryness and thirst, there may be residual heat in the lung meridian; one can use a small amount of ginseng, Poria, and licorice mixed with ginger juice to take cold, or use a teaspoon to add ginger juice to it. For those with deficiency, ginseng soup is permissible.

    Water encompasses heaven and earth, and it has been said by predecessors. Thus, if humanity occupies the middle of heaven and earth, can water also nourish and moisten the five viscera? It is said that heavenly water is generated first, with the kidneys being its main source. The bladder is the receptacle for fluids, thus promoting the flow of kidney water upward to moisten the lungs. Hence, wise practitioners regard the lungs as the organ of fluids, extending from above to below, with the three jiao organs embodying true water of heaven. The "Suwen" states that the origin of water is in the kidneys, and its culmination is in the lungs.[49p]
    When the water does not run out, how can one speak of thirst? People indulge in their desires, excessively consume alcohol, and have a strong craving for rich, spicy, preserved, sour, and salty foods. They also use cinnabar and precious stones to satisfy their desires. Consequently, the fiery heat rises, and their internal organs generate heat, becoming dry and scorching, leading to the drying up of fluids, making them crave water yet unable to restrain themselves.

    The heat ascends, affecting the heart, which becomes empty and diffuse, unable to contain itself. This results in agitation in the chest, a red tongue, and red lips. They often feel thirsty, need to drink frequently, urinate a little, and this condition, attributed to the upper body, is called "wasting thirst."

    If heat accumulates within, and the spleen is weak, it may produce hunger and lead to excessive eating without gaining flesh. This type of thirst is not very bothersome; they merely desire cold drinks, urinate frequently with sweet-smelling urine, and this condition is attributed to the middle body, called "thirst of the middle."

    If heat settles below, affecting the kidneys, the legs and knees become thin and weak, joints ache, and vital essence is exhausted, leading to a need for water that is not overly frequent and sometimes results in abundant and turbid urination. This condition is attributed to the lower body and is called "thirst of the kidneys."

    If one experiences severe wasting thirst, death could ensue. The treatment should primarily focus on nourishing the spleen with white atractylodes powder to generate bodily fluids. It is also beneficial to cook good quality rice into porridge and eat it to strengthen the kidneys, which helps regulate water. Additionally, a clean preparation of coptis can be ground and placed tightly inside a pig's stomach, steamed with some rice until soft, then made into pellets the size of a tung seed. Consuming one hundred pellets, followed by rice and water, can help clear the heart and quench thirst.[50p]
    Hygiene Treasure
    By Luo Tianyi (Yuan Dynasty)

    Distinguishing the Six Meridians of Thirst

    For a Yangming thirst with a floating pulse and no sweat, use remedies like Wuling and Huashi. For a Yangming thirst with a long pulse and sweating, use remedies like Baihu and Liangge. For a Shaoyang thirst with a wiry pulse and vomiting, use Xiao Chaihu Decoction with Melastoma like root. For a Taiyin thirst with a thin pulse and unwillingness to drink water, even if drinking, only thinking of soup and not water, use remedies like Si Junzi and Lizhong Decoction. For a Shaoyin thirst with a sinking pulse and self-relief, use Zhu Ling Decoction and Sanhuang Decoction. For a Jueyin thirst with a faint pulse and a desire to sip, give only a little water.

    Huashi treats thirst primarily due to unbeneficial orifices, as it is drying and can deplete fluid. When excessive dampness is present, it should be used; however, if there is no dampness and it is used, it would be a violation of the rules. If urination is not smooth, whether thirsty or not, it indicates the presence of internal damp-heat.[51p]
    When urination occurs naturally but there is thirst, it indicates internal dryness. Dampness should be dealt with by draining it, while dryness should be addressed with moisturizing; then it will be appropriate. In mixed conditions, if there is sweating and thirst, use a pungent remedy to moisten; if there is no sweating and thirst, use a bitter remedy to strengthen.

    For those with a cold disease, who eat little and feel thirsty, one should employ stomach-regulating medicine to stop the thirst. Cooling medicines should not be used, as they could damage stomach qi, making it even harder to eat. Bai Zhu and Fu Ling are such remedies.

    If there is thirst without sweating in the Taiyang stage, Bai Hu should not be used. If the pulse is strong and rapid after sweating, it may be given. In the Yangming stage, if there is sweating and thirst, Wu Ling should not be used. If urination is impaired, with little sweating and a floating pulse, it should be administered.

    If a person suffers from heat in the heart and lungs but does not feel thirsty, it indicates that the issue is not rooted in the Taiyin or Shaoyin, but is merely superficial. In a superficial condition, there is no thirst; if there is thirst, then it is originating from deeper issues.[52p]
    Collection of Ancient and Modern Books, Complete Record of Medicine, Volume 281

    The Door of Thirst

    Key Points for Diagnosis and Treatment (Ming Dynasty, Dai Sigong)

    Destruction of Thirst

    The three types of "thirst" arise from the excess of qi, the deficiency of blood, and the vacuity of energy. If left untreated for a long time, extreme vacuity of qi leads to an inability to take action. One monk exclusively used a modified Astragalus decoction, emphasizing the enhancement of blood. The three types of thirst involve excessive urination. The upper thirst affects the heart, manifesting as fiery heat ascending with great thirst and increased urination. The middle thirst affects the spleen, resulting in warm dryness, increased appetite, and correspondingly excessive urination. The lower thirst affects the kidneys, where kidney weakness prevents water retention, leading to much urination without thirst. However, with frequent urination, body fluids will inevitably be depleted, and over time, one will experience persistent thirst—regardless of previous claims of being "fully quenched," this is not a valid argument. For the various types of thirst, one should avoid using harsh, drying tonics and instead focus on nourishment. Aside from the spleen type, for the heart and kidney types, it is advisable to use an Astragalus decoction combined with either the Eight Flavor Pill, the Yuan Tu Dan, or the Minor Tu Si Zi Pill. Additionally, Bamboo Dragon Powder can also be used. The Six Divine Decoction is also effective for kidney issues; however, for spleen issues, add Angelica while omitting Astragalus.[53p]
    When there is frequent urination from the three types of wasting, there will certainly be constipation. It is advisable to regularly take the Four Substance Decoction to moisten the large intestine. Adding ginseng, papaya, and pollen, then cooking it into porridge with glutinous rice can also be effective.

    For those with frequent urination that does not smell foul but instead has a sweet scent, stirring up in the urinal, this illness is severe. Additionally, if there are floating substances on the surface of the urine like pig fat and splashes on the sides of the urinal resembling cypress candle tears, this essence is exhausted, leading to a depletion of true vitality.

    In cases of upper and middle wasting, with the heart and spleen being so hot, urination may be scant without restrictions, as there is dryness and heat above and deficiency and cold below, resulting in thirst.

    After prolonged wasting, with vital essence and blood depleted, one may experience blindness or paralysis in the hands and feet like a stroke, which is not wind. This symptom of kidney wasting arises from excess. Wasting of the heart often occurs due to excessive desires for food and drink, as well as the consumption of spicy and hot foods.

    With excessive drinking, urination also increases. It is essential to suppress heart fire to bring it down; naturally, thirst will decrease. One should use Banxia Xiexin Decoction while removing the dry ginger and adding (herbs) like lou and dried kudzu in appropriate amounts. Swallowing pig’s stomach pills or Jiulian pills, along with alone-tasting Huanglian Decoction, should be brewed many times until cooled. When feeling thirsty, drink freely; over time, this will lead to self-recovery.

    Alternatively, porridge made from glutinous rice can be cooked thinly, combined with Ying Soup and Mei Flower Soup, which can be used for those experiencing thirst related to the three types of wasting.[54p]
    If the mind is overexerted, leading to a rise of heart fire and resultant thirst, it is advisable to use a drink made of astragalus combined with half a portion of lotus seeds and polygala, and to swallow Yuan Tu Dan; additionally, boil barley to make a decoction, alternating with Ling Sha Dan.

    To alleviate spleen deficiency, due to the spleen channel being dry and hot, food becomes easily digestible, leading to frequent urination and cyclical hunger. Spleen deficiency is classified into three types: deficiency in the middle, deficiency from cold, and deficiency from heat. For this, it is best to use a drink made of lotus leaves combined with half a portion of raw rehmannia and dried kudzu, or alternatively use the Wu Jin powder or simply the lotus drink.

    If excessive desire leads to disharmony between water and fire, causing kidney water to drain and heart fire to burn, resulting in thirst, cooling heart remedies are not recommended. Instead, one should bolster kidney water to support heart fire. For this purpose, use a drink of astragalus with half a portion of cistanche and five-flavor fruit, swallow Ba Wei Wan and small toosanjia pills, Yuan Tu Dan, deer horn pills, and modified An Shen Wan can all be selected for use, or Ling Sha Dan.[55p]
    Consumption of the kidneys is a serious illness, heavier than other types of consumption. Ancient texts refer to it as "strengthening the center" and "internal consumption." It is often caused by indulgence in sensual desires or by ingesting metals and stones. When kidney energy declines and stone energy remains, there is no essence to nourish, resulting in persistent deficiency. Yang fails to unite with essence, leading to excessive urination, dryness of the lips and mouth.

    For treatment, one can use Huangqi decoction, Tongyuan dan, Bawwei pill, Lurong pill, Jiantian Kidney Energy pill, and Xiaotusi seed pill. If these are ineffective, Huangqi decoction can be augmented with four parts each of Corgong, Beiwuwu, and Shanzhuyu, as well as Jilong pill and Corgong pill.

    In addition to the three types of consumption, there is the thirst from fruit tree consumption, for which musk medications are appropriate. The thirst associated with various illnesses has been addressed in their respective categories.[56p]
    Now, I will specifically mention treatments for those who are thirsty without having a disease, as well as for those who experience thirst after illness. Options include Shenling Powder, Four Gentlemen Decoction, and Spleen-Reducing Decoction, or Qi Zhen Powder augmented with a penny of papaya, all of which may be selected. The Five-Ingredient Powder for Promoting Urination with an addition of a penny of ginseng is called Spring Marsh Decoction; the combination of Five-Ingredient Powder and Four Gentlemen Decoction is also termed Spring Marsh Decoction. This is particularly important, and it is also useful to prepare Four Elderly Congee as food.

    For various diseases that have long-term effects, leading to kidney deficiency and thirst, it is advisable to use Eight-Flavored Pill, Astragalus Decoction, or Four Substance Decoction with half a penny of ginseng and papaya, or Qi Zhen Drink and Great Supplement Decoction, excluding the herb Atractylodes, while adding papaya as needed.

    For those who have lost blood or for postpartum women experiencing thirst during confinement, this is called blood thirst, and it is important to seek remedies that nourish the blood, which has already been discussed in the main text.

    If a person suddenly experiences intense thirst without an underlying condition but the thirst subsides after a short while, it is best to use honey water and Spleen-Reducing Decoction, while also drinking a few sips of cool rice gruel or the like.

    For those who experience thirst from alcohol consumption, a mixture of dry kudzu root with Five-Ingredient Powder should be used.[57p]
    Medical Summary
    By Lou Ying, Ming Dynasty

    Xiao Ke (Diabetes)

    Upper Xiao refers to what is known as "ge xiao." Ge xiao means thirst accompanied by excessive drinking. Middle Xiao is referred to as "xiao zhong." Xiao zhong means thirst with increased eating and drinking; or drinking alone without thirst. Lower Xiao is referred to as "shen xiao." Shen xiao means drinking once leads to urination twice, with urine resembling greasy oil. This is a transformation from ge xiao or xiao zhong. Wang’s commentary states: “Lung energy is exhausted and cannot retain.” The lungs store energy, and when they are healthy, they can manage and gather fluids. The refined essence of these fluids nourishes tendons, bones, and blood vessels, while the remainder is expelled as urine. When the lungs are diseased, they cannot manage the fluids, and the refined essence is also lost through urine, leading to excessive urination that resembles greasy oil. Without sufficient fluids to nourish tendons, bones, and blood vessels, diseases manifest gradually, causing thinness and dryness. However, lung diseases originate from kidney deficiency. When the kidneys are deficient, the heart becomes fearful; excessive actions harm the lungs, leading coldness to invade, and then lung disease develops. Thus, Zhong Jing treated thirst with an increased volume of urination using Shenqi Pills to replenish the kidneys and assist the lungs; hence, later generations termed it "shen xiao" and "lower xiao."[58p]
    Some say: The scriptures state that when lung consumption leads to death and cannot be treated, why does Zhong Jing use Shen Qi Wan to address it? I say: If the patient drinks one measure and urinates two, it is beyond treatment. However, if they drink one and have not yet urinated twice, the illness is still mild and may be treatable. Thus, Zhong Jing's Shen Qi Wan is used for conditions where one drinks a斗 (a unit of measure) of water and also urinates a斗 of fluid. If the urine exceeds the intake, it is also beyond assistance.

    Irregularity in diet and exhaustion weaken the spleen and stomach, leading to illnesses of blood, which primarily cause the fluids in the mouth to fail to circulate, resulting in dryness of the mouth and throat. The patient mistakenly believes they are thirsty, leading the physician to use Wu Ling San to treat it, which instead exacerbates thirst and dryness, resulting in serious depletion of fluids and risk of death. The scriptures say: "When there is deficiency, one must nourish its mother." Therefore, one should nourish the heart and small intestine. This is fundamental support for the spleen and stomach, using sweet and warm medicines as the main treatment, bitter cold as the means, and sour as the assisting ministers. When the heart is deficient, one should quickly consume sour substances to gather it; if heart fire is strong, the lung metal suffers from pathogenic influences, and when metal is deficient, it should be nourished with sour substances; then add sweet and warm, and sweet and cold agents, to drain the excess heart fire from the spleen and stomach. This is addressing the root of the issue.[59p]
    Introduction to Medicine
    By Li Chan (Ming Dynasty)

    Xiaoke (Diabetes)

    The classics say: The condition called Xiaoke is due to the binding of the two Yangs. The two Yangs refer to the Hand Yangming (large intestine) governing fluids and the Foot Yangming (stomach) governing blood. When fluids and blood are insufficient, it leads to Xiaoke. There is also a condition of dryness and blockage, as the lungs and large intestine are interrelated.

    For thirst due to Qi deficiency, it occurs from external pathogens invading inward, or from consuming excessively dry food, causing heat to deplete fluids. Such individuals prefer drinking cold water; they should be given cold and cooling diuretics to clear the heat. Once the heat dissipates, Yin is restored and thirst will subside.

    For thirst due to blood deficiency, it is caused by internal injuries or overwork, leading to depletion of spirit and a failure of stomach Qi to rise. This can occur after illness when the stomach is weak and fluids are depleted, or from residual heat in the lungs, resulting in a dry mouth and thirst. Such individuals prefer hot soup; they should be given warming and nourishing agents to replenish Yin. Once Yin is restored, dryness will lessen and thirst will cease.

    The term "Xiao" means to burn, akin to how fire cooks and burns. When the three types of Xiao (upper, middle, lower) are balanced, the condition does not descend further. The upper is light, the middle is heavy, and the lower is critical. Ultimately, all arise from the lungs being attacked by fire pathogens, enduring for a long time, causing stagnation of Qi and blood. Thus, those who can eat experience overflow of fluids leading to abscesses; those who cannot eat suffer from distention and increased internal heat. Both conditions are critical.[60p]
    Heat in the upper jiao causes agitation of the heart and lungs, with a red tongue and red lips. If there is little appetite and frequent urination, one should take Siwu Decoction combined with Shengmai Powder plus Tianhuafen, Dihuang juice, lotus root juice, and milk. For drinkers, add kudzu juice. If one can eat, use Baihu Decoction with ginseng; if not, use Qian's Baizhu Powder or Qingxin Lotus Seed Drink. If there is fullness in the diaphragm, it is called diaphragm exhaustion, and one should use Mendan Drink. When heat penetrates the flesh and transforms into abscesses, use Jinyenteng Pill, Huaiqi Liuyi Decoction, or Yiyuan Powder.

    Heat accumulating in the middle jiao leads to symptoms like the spleen and stomach being weakened with an increased appetite but not much thirst, red and frequent urination, and constipation. Use Siwu Decoction with Zhimu, Huangbai, Shigao, Huangqin, and Huashi to clear the heat. In severe cases, use Tiaogui Chengqi Decoction or Sanhuang Pill. When the illness starts with cold leading to excess yin and then transforms to heat in the middle, use Shengma Gekun Decoction or Xiehuang Powder. For toxin due to damp accumulation, use Xiaopi Pill. For deficiency, use Qian's Baizhu Powder. For blocked bowels, use Danggui Runzi Decoction. For diarrhea, use Baizhu Shaoyao Decoction. For both upward and downward reflux, use Lanxiang Drink. When heart fire invades the spleen, use Huanglian Zhu's Stomach Pill.[61p]
    If the liver invades the qi, leading to hot body temperature and loss of appetite, with the risk of vomiting worms upon eating, administer Wumei Pills or Iron Powder Pills. For those with worms consuming their body fluids, use Dan Kuliang Decoction. If water accumulates below and transforms into a distended lump, use Sanling Powder, or remove the cinnamon and add ginseng for better effect.

    When heat lurks in the lower abdomen, causing depletion of essence from the kidneys, and water self-harms, leading to immediate urination with cloudy urine resembling cream, emaciated legs and knees, dark complexion, and scorched ears, the prescription is Siwu Decoction with added Zhimu, Huangbo, Wuweizi, Yuanshen, and human milk, to harmonize water and fire; it can also be supplemented with Yin Pill, Kidney Qi Pill, or Kanli Pill, and Bamei Pill removing Aconite while adding Wuweizi, Yuandudan, and Lutu Pill, along with Mengshou Tianwang Heart-Supplementing Pill, Wei Xi Pill, Miaoxiang Powder, or Danjian Silk Decoction; or Shiquan Dabu Decoction removing cinnamon, doubling the earth essence while adding Zhimu and Huangbo.

    For those with excess heat above and cold below, use Qingxin Lianzidan Drink. If someone has excessive stone energy and their true qi is exhausted while the stone energy remains, causing the yang pathway to become strong without mingling essence and leakage, this state is referred to as "strong inside."[62p]
    Urine may be oily, red-yellow, or pale white; it may be accompanied by thirst and frequent urination, or thirst without urination, or urination without thirst. When food and drink enter the stomach, it is like pouring soup on snow, and it is expelled with urine, forming a residue like white fat. Those who grow thinner daily have no remedy.

    To treat thirst, initially nourish the lungs and descend the heart, then for a long time nourish the kidneys and strengthen the spleen. The root cause lies in the kidneys, while the symptoms are in the lungs. When the kidneys are warm, qi rises and the lungs are moistened; when the kidneys are cold, qi does not rise and the lungs dry out. Therefore, the Kidney Qi Pill is an excellent remedy for thirst. However, both the heart and kidneys connect through the spleen; nourishing the spleen will naturally produce bodily fluids, as seen in the Ginseng and Atractylodes Powder. For the three types of wasting and thirsting, the use of Single Clam Powder is advised, mixed with water for intake, to restore fluids and quench thirst. The Single (Herb) Stem Pill is a divine remedy for thirst. Avoid 半夏 (Banxia) drying agents.

    Water encompasses heaven and earth, and the organs of the human body are also enveloped in fluid and true water. The tangible forms of water, such as exchanges and the earth, are what we consider as water; while the intangible is the water born of the sky, which is qi, linked to the trigram Kan (Water) and Qian (Heaven). To manage the intangible water with the intangible fire, this is known as 'Completed Accomplishment.'

    For mixed diseases, there is a prevalence of excess thirst and deficient heat, while true heat is less common. After onset of thirst, acupuncture should be avoided, as it may draw out fluids and lead to death.

    — Medical Commentary by Zhao Xianke (Ming Dynasty)

    — On Thirst and Wasting[63p]
    Upper消 (xiaosh消) refers to a condition where the tongue is red and cracked, leading to extreme thirst. The reverse adjustment theory says that heat from the heart transforms and transmits to the lungs, resulting in upper消. This can be treated with Bai Hu Tang (White Tiger Decoction) with added ginseng.

    Middle消 (zhongxiaosh消) is characterized by good appetite but thinness, spontaneous sweating, hard stools, and frequent urination. Shuhe states that a dry mouth and increased thirst, along with excessive eating leading to muscular weakness and the formation of middle消, can be treated with Tiaowei Chengqi Decoction.

    Lower消 (xiash消) presents with restlessness and thirst, dry and burnt ears, and urination resembling oil. Shuhe indicates that the intense thirst and irritability suggest this is kidney消. It can be treated with Liuwu Wan (Six-Flavor Pill).

    The ancient methods to treat the three jiaos (sanjiao) are detailed, but I have another perspective. When a person's water and fire are balanced, and their qi and blood are adequately nourished, there should be no消. However, if there is improper nourishment, with water and fire imbalanced, fluids become dried out, leading to a fiery upward blaze. Prolonged boiling leads to digestive exhaustion, and the five organs become dry, resulting in emaciation and fatigue. Therefore, the method to treat消 should not divide into upper, middle, or lower; rather, one should prioritize treating the kidney as urgent. Only the Six-Flavor, Eight-Flavor, and modified Eight-Flavor Pills should be taken according to symptoms, reducing heart fire and nourishing kidney water, thus alleviating thirst. Bai Hu and Chengqi should not be used for treatment.

    The "Comprehensive Records" states that those who can't eat but are thirsty indicate a fullness in the middle that is not transmitted; those who can eat and are thirsty are likely to develop abscesses on the back of the neck. The inability to eat points to a problem with the spleen, which should nourish the surrounding areas and work with the stomach to manage fluids. If both the spleen and stomach are deficient, they cannot distribute their fluids, leading to thirst. Even if a person can eat, it is a sign of a weak stomach trying to remedy itself.[64p]
    If one indiscriminately uses cold and cooling herbs to clear heat, such as the White Tiger Decoction or the Chengqi Decoction, then the internal heat will not be cleared, and cold will reappear, leading to distension—how can that avoid transmission? Only formulas such as the Seven Ingredient Bai Zhu Powder or the Ren Shen Sheng Mai Powder should be used, allowing for ample drinking, while also using the Eight Flavor Rehmannia Pill to nourish the source of transformation. That is the correct method of treatment. If one can eat and feels thirsty, and develops ulcers, that is a disease of the wealthy, indulging in rich foods. They frequently consume sweet and fatty foods, thus their upper qi overflows and causes thirst. One should not take rich foods or fragrant herbs, as their energy is harsh and can exacerbate dryness and heat. The classics say: “To treat it with orchids is to remove the stale qi.” One should also avoid cold and cooling remedies and those that cause abscesses. Why is that? The classics state: “The transformation from rich foods leads to numerous large sores.” That is what is meant.[65p]
    When the kidney is deficient and there are brain abscesses or back sores, it is said that the kidney governs the bones, and the brain is the sea of the kidneys. The back corresponds to the area affected by cold water passing through the Shaoyang channel. When the water is drained and the sea is depleted, and the yin fire rises, how can abscesses and sores not develop? If the sores are severe but do not ulcerate, they may present as red fluid; if extreme, they may appear black or purple. The fire’s intensity resembles the essence of water, indicating that the kidney's water has been exhausted and cannot be treated. However, if one might strongly replenish the yin, there may still be a chance to save it.

    Someone asks: Why do people who take Rehmannia Decoction remain thirsty and cannot be quenched? The answer is: These practitioners cannot abandon their established methods and try a new approach. The heart and lungs are positioned closely, so a smaller dose is appropriate; conversely, the kidney and liver are farther apart, allowing for a larger dose. For conditions with high or middle level consumption, one may use pills in moderation to treat them. However, if lower consumption is at its peak, with great thirst and dryness, one must increase or adjust the eight-flavor pill's dosage to one sheng, adding one liang of cinnamon, boiling it in six or seven bowls of water, and drinking it iced to indulge. If one sleeps well, their thirst problem will be resolved.

    The formulation of prescriptions depends on the adaptability of the person.

    Another inquiry: For lower consumption without water, using the Six-Flavor Rehmannia Pill can nourish the kidney water of the less yin; why add Aconite and Cinnamon? It is because the fire at the Mingmen is weak and cannot transform food and water; the essence of food and water cannot ascend to moisten the lungs, like a cauldron without fuel, leaving the pot dry, hence the thirst.[66p]
    As for the lungs, they have nothing to depend on; they are unable to distribute the essence of water evenly, and operate through the five organs. The water one drinks, if not processed by fire, directly enters the bladder, which means drinking one liter results in one liter of urine, and drinking one斗 results in one斗 of urine. If you taste it, it is sweet but not salty, which is evident. Therefore, using the warming and pungent properties of Aconite and Cinnamon strengthens their slight heat. Adding firewood under the stove, as dry rice grains benefit from rain, new life emerges. Only the wise understand this, while the ignorant often consider it impractical. In the past, Emperor Wu of Han suffered from thirst, and Zhang Zhongjing prescribed this formula, now known in the Sacred Yuan Pass, and it can still be recalled today. The Eight Flavor Pill is indeed a good remedy. After wounds and sores heal, and for those who are very thirsty just before recovery, with a yellow, hard tongue; and for those who suffer from thirst beforehand, or those who feel restless and thirsty, with frequent urination, or cloudy discharges, loss of appetite, thin body, swollen legs and thin feet, mouth sores – anyone who takes it will find it effective.[67p]
    A nobleman fell ill with a disease, and while his condition had not yet stabilized, he became exceedingly thirsty. One day he drank several liters of water. Out of foolishness, I offered a modified version of the Rehmannia formula. The other doctors laughed aloud, saying, "If this medicine can quench thirst, we would no longer need to practice medicine." They all prescribed medicines like papaya, perilla, black plum, ginseng, poria, and various decoctions to generate bodily fluids, but his thirst only intensified. After several doses, there was no effect whatsoever. Reluctantly, they resorted to the previous formula, and after three days, his thirst ceased. Because of my belief in the long-term efficacy of this medicine, not only did his thirst disappear, but his vitality was also strengthened, and his appetite increased, surpassing even his youth. This usage of the medicine is not just based on my narrow view; it indeed has historical roots. The Xue family has preserved this formula, having used it with verified results multiple times. Hence, I detail it here so that those suffering from thirst can trust its efficacy, dedicatedly use the medicine, and not be misled by mediocre doctors, thereby expanding upon the wisdom of our predecessors. Long-term use lightens the body, sharpens the senses, and brings luminosity to one's appearance.[68p]
    The five flavors mainly found in the north are particularly effective, especially for replenishing kidney water and calming the fiery energy of the heart. Among these, the herb cinnamon must not be neglected; if it is removed, the remedy will be ineffective.

    A man suffering from this condition attempted to treat it with a previous formula but replaced cinnamon with drugs such as coptis and anemarrhena, believing that cinnamon is too warming. He remained relentlessly thirsty, developed back sores, and ultimately died. Indeed, cinnamon is a medicinal ingredient for the kidney channel. The previous signs indicated a deficiency of kidney fire rising upwards, which, without proper regulation, became harmful; thus, cinnamon was used to guide other medicines to nourish and redirect the deficient fire back to its source, leading to its efficacy. Cheng Wujin states: Cinnamon is particularly guiding, aiding in directing yang energy, like a harness that leads the flow.

    As for the issue of upward consumption, it refers to heat from the heart moving into the lungs; and for middle consumption, it refers to internal deficiencies causing stomach heat. All recognize heat as harmful, which leads to the use of formulas like Bai Hu or Cheng Qi, ultimately resulting in failure to save the patient.[69p]
    In summary, this concerns the lower burner and the vital gate; when the fire does not return to its origin and wanders in the lungs, it results in upper depletion; when it wanders in the stomach, it results in middle depletion. Using the Eight Flavor Kidney Qi Pill to draw the fire back to its origin allows the fire to settle at the bottom of the cauldron, balancing water and fire. When the Qi rises and steams, the lungs suffer from dampness, leading to thirst and illness recovery.

    There is a type of thirst that seeks to drink, but the person quickly becomes weary after just one or two sips of water, soon feeling thirsty again. They can only drink a little, unlike those with true thirst who drink without limit. This indicates a deficiency of middle Qi and coldness, where cold water rises to push against the wandering fire in the throat and tongue; hence, the upper burner craves water for relief. However, reaching the middle burner, the water encounters water and intensifies what is undesirable. Treatment: if the face is red and the person is agitated, administer the Li Zhong Decoction together with the Eight Flavor Pill.

    Another type of thirst involves wanting to drink water but immediately vomits it back up after swallowing; shortly after, the person seeks more to drink but can hardly take in any food or medicine. This indicates an excess of yin obstructing yang, a sign of kidney channel injury due to cold. Zhang Zhongjing added human urine and bile to the Bai Tong formula, utilizing hot medicine with a cold exploration method; a single dose can lead to recovery. Many women experience this condition.[70p]
    Discussion on Thirst and Consumption

    The affliction of thirst often begins subtly and becomes pronounced, starting in the stomach and culminating in the lungs and kidneys. At first, it is like watering a burning fire; water can still extinguish it. But later, it becomes like pouring water on a stone; when the water is gone, the stone remains unchanged. When drinking and urinating becomes frequent, it consumes the true yin with dryness and fire, leading to exhaustion. According to the "Inner Canon," there are discussions but no treatments. The "Golden Chamber" contains both discussions and treatments. However, compilers have conflated the discussions in "Treatise on Cold Damage" concerning the Throat Meridian's thirst, leading later generations to be unable to distinguish appropriateness, which is also unsuitable for application. The transmission of cold damage indicates that when the heat pathogen reaches the Throat Meridian, it is entirely manifested; when heat penetrates deeply, thirst arises and consumption occurs. Once the heat resolves, there is no thirst and no consumption. Is this comparable to conditions arising from accumulated symptoms? I humbly propose a discussion based on the "Inner Canon." The texts say that in treating conditions like consumption, collapse, atrophy, weakness, and rebellious qi in the abdomen, afflictions among the wealthy are due to rich foods, which are the sources of consumption. The wealthy who are not overweight may lack fresh food, while the overweight who are not wealthy might overindulge.[71p]
    Fatty and expensive, rich wine with thick flavor—are these limited in quantity? Over time, consuming them generates internal heat, and bodily fluids dry up, leading one to seek relief from water. However, when water enters, it can still alleviate this, but the more it alleviates, the thirstier one becomes. The richer the food consumed, the worse the inner heat becomes, leading to the illness of internal consumption. Once this internal consumption manifests, it transmits through various pathways, whether upward or downward, especially in areas of intense heat.

    Upper consumption occurs when the stomach, heated, affects the lungs, burdening the body. The heart, also heated, transfers this heat to the lungs, resulting in suffering for the metal (lungs). Metal is the source of water that emerges from higher origins. When consumed in the stomach, the essence overflows and rises, the lungs adjust the water pathways downward. Now, when heated, the water from the high source is violently pressured, mixing with externally consumed water, rushing down uncontrollably. Urinating often does not merely fail to eliminate external water, but also exhausts and drains the essence of innate water, leading to significant excess in waste discharge.

    Therefore, without treatment, one dies. The so-called "death of yin" related to the heart and lungs, where death can occur within three days, refers to this. Thus, urinating often—first sign of danger.[72p]
    As for the stomach, its heat is transmitted down through the gate to the kidneys. The kidneys may be depleted by stone medicine, exhausting their essence. When a woman experiences this, yang is strong externally, while yin cannot maintain itself internally. This leads to cloudy urination like sludge; after drinking, urination occurs frequently, indicating kidney depletion. The classics mention that the nature of stone medicine is harsh, and it is said that the wind from the spleen transmits to the kidneys, causing what is known as hernia and distension, with pain in the lower abdomen and the discharge of white fluid, referred to as "gu." This clearly indicates kidney depletion.

    A physician named He states: Women possess yang; indulgence leads to internal heat and the affliction of "gu." This elaboration on internal heat and the meaning of "gu" is quite clear. The Grand Minister Wang said: Depletion consumes the flesh like "gu" erodes. This is clearly evident from the term "depletion," which is rather shallow. Indeed, being obsessed with women's beauty results in loss of will, and excessive loss of essence leads to turbid fluids, transforming back into a fire, which is the most perilous condition. The classics state: "When the ruler's fire descends, yin essence supports it." Therefore, if there is an excess of yin essence, it is sufficient to support heart fire, signifying longevity; if yin essence is insufficient, heart fire will descend directly to the kidneys, leading to a decline in yang essence, resulting in premature death.

    Thus, the kidneys serve as the gate of the stomach; if the gate lacks openness, water cannot be released and leads to swelling. If the gate is not closed, water is unceasingly expelled, resulting in thirst. Thirst is a condition belonging to the kidneys; the original text of "Jin Kui" remains unaltered, stating that when one drinks a dou, they urinate a dou, which is governed by kidney qi.[73p]
    Then steam transforms essence into water, ascending to receive the fire of the ruler, while halting the lower entry of the Yang energy. This is the true communication between heaven and earth. Zhang Zihe dared to disparage it. After denigrating Zhongjing, he praised Hejian, claiming its Shenxiong pill, made with the bitter taste of Huangqin, enters the heart, while Qianniu and Dahuang drive down the fire energy, using Shalstone to channel into the kidney meridian, effectively taking it away from the Kan. This truly grasps the secret of the Huangting. He twists this doctrine to cater to his own preferences, with a shallow understanding that is hardly worthy to enter Zhongjing’s door. He Bai's "Treatise on Diabetes" has already clarified its errors. Chang Guan's accounts have never treated diabetes, proving that without the issue, there can be no reasoning behind it. The discussion on fire at the beginning is not without its reason. However, applying the principle of purging Qi to treat vigorous fire leads to no effective result for diabetes. Thus, the fire of below diabetes is akin to fire in water; lowering it only intensifies the burn. The fire of middle diabetes is akin to the draining fire of marshes; lowering it only causes more harm. The fire of upper diabetes is like a wildfire; water that falls from heaven can extinguish it. Merely attacking the intestines and stomach is of no benefit, and instead causes harm. The earth's energy rises as clouds, and in turn, the heavens’ energy descends as rain; thus, rain arises from the earth's energy. If the earth’s energy does not rise, can the heavens rain? Therefore, it is imperative to elevate the earth's energy to nourish the three farmers, as well as to elevate the kidney's energy to irrigate the three burners—both are necessary truths. Not distinguishing this from the ancients, how can later generations adhere to what is clear?[74p]

    Continuation of the Discussion

    In "On Thirst," Chang discusses the essence of the "Inner Canon," stating that it begins in the stomach and culminates in the lungs and kidneys, defining the three areas of consumption as being upper and middle. Other conditions like diaphragm consumption and food-related issues are also just forms of upper and middle consumption. However, without practical references from the "Essential Prescription," my heart remained unsatisfied. Two years later, I suddenly remembered the "Inner Canon" stating: when there is labor and fatigue, the physical energy diminishes, and the energy of grains is not abundant. The upper burner does not function well, the stomach's energy is hot, and this heat disturbs the chest, resulting in internal heat. I realized that the disease in the chest is solely due to the energy of food and grain in the stomach, which circulates and nourishes the chest, allowing for clarity and brightness to manifest in one's own body.[75p]
    If there is fatigue or weariness that harms the fundamental energy and vital essence, then the energy in the chest becomes weak; the digestive energy in the stomach thereby does not thrive. When the digestive energy does not thrive, the injured energy in the chest becomes even harder to recover, and cannot be adequately replenished. Consequently, the digestive energy remains stagnant in the stomach, causing stagnation and heat within. This heat then pervades the chest, mixing with the weakened energy and transforming into internal heat. The balance between the chest and stomach becomes unsettled, making it impossible to avoid thirst and depletion.

    Understanding this key point clarifies what has been previously misunderstood in the "Golden Chamber" text. It states: if the pulse at the wrist is floating and slow, the floating indicates deficiency, and the slow indicates fatigue. Deficiency implies insufficient protective energy, and fatigue means that the nourishing energy is depleted. If the pulse at the foot is floating and rapid, the floating signifies energy, and the rapid indicates that the digestive process is impaired and there is excessive solidity; abundant energy results in quick urination, and quick urination indicates solidity. When solidity and rapidity collide, this signifies thirst.

    By examining the wrist pulse, one can assess the energy in the chest; by examining the pulse at the foot, one can assess the energy in the stomach. Clearly, there is a pulse to follow and evident signs to observe, yet it is difficult to discern the subtleties. The essence lies in the fact that yin resides within, safeguarding the yang; yang is outside, reinforcing the yin. A floating pulse at the wrist indicates that yin is not properly maintaining itself internally, thus, the yang in the external protective layer is floating and signifies deficiency. A slow pulse at the wrist indicates that yang is not effectively anchored externally, therefore, the yin safeguarding internally is slow and signifies fatigue. Overall, it is the injury of nourishing and protective energies that causes the wrist pulse to be deficient and slow. The nourishing energy pertains to the essence of food and water, while the protective energy pertains to their robust qualities. When both are deficient and slow, the energy from food and water fails to rise and fills the interior with stagnation, which is already evident of a weak diaphragm and stomach heat.[76p]
    In addition to the floating pulse of the Fuyang meridian, when it is floating it represents Qi, which corresponds to the changes described in the "Inner Canon" regarding heat Qi scorching the chest; when it is rapid, it indicates the consumption of food and the presence of a large hardness. In the earlier discussion, it is like water being poured over a stone: when the water is gone, the stone remains unchanged. This coincides with the presence of hardness in the stomach, where food is consumed but water is not, illustrating that the heat of fire can consume water, while water can quench thirst. When the stomach is hard and dry, it does not absorb water; instead, it is driven by the force of heat, leading to rapid urination, resulting in frequent urination. This depletion exacerbates dryness, thus the hardness and frequency clash, constituting thirst. Directly referencing the "Inner Canon," excessive bitterness, prolonged exposure to heat transforms it, and the spleen's Qi is not moistened, leading to a thickened stomach Qi — this is the source of thirst, both subtle and significant. After the Jin and Tang dynasties, while there were many who were wise and insightful, interpreting the "Inner Canon," each rising figure became notable in their own right, yet none entered the profound teachings of Zhang Zhongjing, as what they obtained from the "Inner Canon" was shallow. Had they delved deeper, they could have correlated conditions, compared symptoms, and derived treatments based on pulse and symptomology to clarify established methods, but the remnants of the "Golden Cabinet" have been passed down and recited in households.[77p]
    Just as in cases of thirst, it is traditionally said that those with mid-thirst should be treated with purgatives, adhering to this principle without other considerations. Can one resolve the issue with just one treatment? Or should it be approached progressively? The stomach has become large and firm and does not accept nourishment easily; just administering purgatives may not yield results. The firm does not respond, while the weak does. The bladder does not act, but the large intestine does; could this not lead to complications driven by the medication, resulting in issues like fullness and swelling? The "Comprehensive Record" states: those who are able to eat but develop boils will inevitably suffer from severe swelling; those who cannot eat will certainly experience abdominal fullness and bloating, all of which are signs of an illness that cannot be treated. Various schools do not focus on the initial stages of the disease but rather on the later stages, employing many treatments like honeysuckle, blue leaves, and herbal pills, as well as combinations for abdominal fullness. What is their intention? The "Golden Cabinet" suggests that in instances of slight urinary discomfort, one should early on use only clam as treatment, which is not mentioned in published formulas. Little do they know that softening and firming substances, if not treating deficiency can injure it, while this particular one is benign, effective for diuresis, and truly precious! Jiegao states: for those who can eat but are thirsty, one should use White Tiger Decoctio with ginseng. For those who cannot eat but are thirsty, one should use the Qian family's white atractylodes powder with kudzu root. The late-stage boils are a result of excessive fire; one must urgently attack the Yang, not the Yin. The fundamental qi of the lower region: if strengthened, life arises; if weakened, death ensues.[78p]
    The text discusses the medical philosophy regarding the treatment of illnesses associated with excess heat and cold in the body. It emphasizes the importance of understanding the nature of the illness and the appropriate treatment methods. It criticizes rushing to use remedies without considering their effects on the body. The reference to the "pure ancient elder" suggests a reverence for traditional wisdom, particularly in avoiding aggressive treatments that could worsen a patient's condition. The mention of the three types of wasting diseases (消) relates to fire pathology, arguing that one must recognize how heat impacts different organs and should treat accordingly. It warns against merely addressing symptoms without understanding the root causes, illustrating the complexity of balancing yin and yang within the body. This balance is crucial in effective healing methods, and the text concludes by referencing the "Inner Canon" which classifies illnesses related to the emergence of excess yang as wasting diseases.[79p]
    The "two Yangs" refers to the Yangming. The Yangming of the hand rules the large intestine and governs fluids; when disease leads to deficiency, one experiences yellowing of the eyes and dryness of the mouth, indicating insufficient fluids. The Yangming of the foot governs the stomach and rules the blood; when disease is hot, there is a tendency for excessive hunger and a lurking fire in the blood, indicating insufficient blood. A blockage arises from a lack of fluids and blood; when blocked and not moving, it is a disease caused by dryness.

    The "Neijing" states: the heart transfers heat to the lungs, which results in diaphragm dysfunction. Zhang Zihe suggests that diaphragm dysfunction has not yet reached the lungs; when the heart transfers cold to the lungs, this constitutes lung dysfunction. By muddying the text, one misunderstands the "Neijing." How could it be that the heart transfers heat to the lungs, and the lungs pass that heat to the diaphragm, but it has not yet affected the lungs? It is necessary to change the text to state that the heart transfers heat to the diaphragm, which then transmits it to the lungs, thereby avoiding confusion.

    It must be understood that the heart and lungs both reside above the diaphragm, with the lungs being a delicate organ. Cold and heat can easily enter; however, when cold pathogens enter, they are bound externally, while hot pathogens enter and transmit outward. Both affect the lung tips, but treatment must differentiate them.

    Liu Hejian discussed the disease of the "three consumptions," attributing it to extreme depletion of the cold-deficient yin and excessive surplus of the hot-strong yang, leaving out the elements of wind and fire from the six influences.[80p]
    The conditions known as "Three Privations"—namely, consuming thirst, consuming in the middle, and consuming of the kidneys—are categorized as such. Can there truly be a consumption of the middle and lower without thirst? It is stated in the texts that thirst can arise from various causes: heart and lung qi stagnation leading to thirst, liver blockage causing thirst, heat obstruction leading to thirst, stomach and large intestine heat causing thirst, spleen blockage resulting in thirst, kidney heat causing thirst, and small intestine heat causing thirst. The more one examines these causes, the more one finds them lacking in clarity regarding consuming thirst, merely citing thirst as a manifestation of dryness and heat depleting fluids, which is indeed puzzling.

    In the "Essentials of the Jade Mechanism," there is a deep discussion on this, erroneously attributing the cure for consumption to warming remedies for the kidneys; I am unsure what such warming medicines truly entail. Is there any reasoning in the world that a warming remedy could treat consuming thirst? The implication likely lies in the fact that it is not based on the "Golden Cabinet" principle of Kidney Qi Pills. Yet Kidney Qi Pills invigorate kidney water and are known as the miraculous remedy for consuming thirst, recognized by later generations. Why then does Bai Zhai further elaborate on this?

    I am concerned that later scholars might casually come across the discussions of Zi He and Zong Hou, which might confuse and mislead them further, prompting me to restate this point. The condition called "Dampness" leads to consuming in the middle, with intense stomach heat and excessive stomach fire, resulting in an increased appetite and thirst. Various schools suggest the use of Major Decoction to Purge for treatment. However, they fail to recognize that the accumulated heat, which has gradually developed, and the inherent fire will not be resolved by aggressive purging. Merely purging will be harmful to the intestines and stomach and will worsen the discomfort.[81p]
    Therefore, when necessary to use rhubarb, it must be long steamed to harmonize its properties. Moreover, it should not be combined with bitter orange or amomum, as this would exacerbate the urgency of the illness. The ancient remedy known as "Shunli Powder" implies a gentle approach, avoiding aggression.

    The formula states: for treating internal heat in the stomach that affects appetite, with slight yellowish red urine and minimal urination, if one loses the desire to eat, it should not be overutilized. I fear that minimal urination leading to loss of appetite indicates that the stomach qi is already depleted. The method of purging medicine is not to be recklessly applied.

    You harmonize this formula into "Jiajian Sanyuan Pill," combining rhubarb with Scutellaria and Coptis, while not using bitter orange or amomum. The formula also addresses the toxicity and heat caused by mineral medications. By intuition, it must be used with substantial effectiveness, considering whether the condition of dryness is due to the body's genuine qi being consumed by excessive heat. Is there truly anyone of substantial build?

    Thus, to eliminate the heat from the stomach, what must be done? I believe that prolonged steaming of rhubarb, combined with licorice, can provide a balanced approach to quickening and soothing. When used with ginseng, it can simultaneously attack and tonify, similar to enhancing agricultural production in a prosperous land, enduring initial challenges, thereby hoping for benefits over three years. Currently, even if there are opportunities for quick gains, they should not be pursued, as how could one expect immediate results? The ancient sages have surpassed this understanding.[82p]
    When treating initial stages of thirst disease, one should not hastily produce fluids to replenish water or lower heat. Inadequate use of medicine prolongs suffering, which is the physician's fault.

    When treating middle stage of thirst disease, one should not urgently revive the organs tied to metal and water; when the source is exhausted and there are no signs of recovery, this is the physician's fault.

    When treating pulmonary thirst disease, using dihuang pills for blood issues, or using Baihu decoction for kidney issues, if one adheres to a single approach without addressing the whole, the illness cannot be resolved, which is the physician's fault.

    If thirst disease shows little improvement, one should not hastily return to dry and parched conditions, ignoring that the soil is dry and unproductive, leading to the brewing of sores and abscesses without remedy, which is the physician's fault.

    The "Mendong Drink" is suitable for elderly and weak individuals suffering from excessive thirst.[83p]
    In treating diabetes, excessive use of cold and cool treatments can overwhelm the body's fire, even leading to water overpowering fire—a failure to recognize this can result in swelling and fullness beyond recovery, which is the fault of the physician.

    The illness of the three types of diabetes is related to the three burners. The upper diabetes, characterized by extreme thirst, leads to constant drinking; this depletes the fluids in the upper burner. It has been said that the disease lies in the lungs, yet it is also due to the heat from the heart and spleen, which can scorch these areas, hence it is also called phlegm diabetes. The middle diabetes pertains to the middle burner, where excessive eating leads to hunger without increasing flesh, resulting in gradual weight loss; this disease is located in the spleen and stomach, also referred to as ingestion diabetes. The lower diabetes concerns the lower burner, where urine is yellow and turbid, sometimes resembling fat or grease, with the face dark and ears scorched, involving gradual weight loss; this ailment is in the kidneys, thus also known as kidney diabetes.

    The ancients recognized all three types as manifestations of fire disease, yet there are cases of real fire caused by excess heat, and instances of false fire from insufficient true yin. If one treats diabetes without distinguishing between excess and deficiency, errors are inevitable. Understanding the distinctions of yin and yang in diabetes is crucial. For example, excessive thirst is termed "thirst diabetes," excessive hunger is termed "grain diabetes," and turbid urine resembling fat indicates "kidney diabetes."[84p]
    All of this arises mainly because a strong fire leads to a deficiency of yin, which is a sign of the consumption of yang. However, the meaning of yin consumption is not well understood by many. Consumption refers to both dissolution and depletion. Any decline and failure of the yin-yang, blood, or qi is termed consumption, so one cannot entirely explain it in terms of fire. How can this be demonstrated? For instance, the theory of qi collapse states: "When the heart is influenced by cold in the lungs, it leads to lung consumption; after drinking one or two urinations, death occurs without treatment." This is precisely due to the decline of foundational qi, leading to coldness in metal and water; thus, water fails to transform into qi, while all qi transforms into water. Isn't this a manifestation of yin deficiency presenting as a sign of yang? Furthermore, the chapter on pathogenic influences in organs says: "When the pulses of the five organs are thin and small, it signifies consumption and stagnation." Can one consider these thin pulses as signs of excess yang? This clearly illustrates the concept of yin consumption in the "Inner Classic," which is not well comprehended by people. Therefore, when treating the three signs of consumption, one must observe the pulses and the nature of the disease. If one only notes the deficiency of foundational qi and associated signs of false heat, they must swiftly address the root cause to nourish the source of transformation. Merely recognizing the condition as fire and focusing on clearing it will inevitably result in both yin and yang failing.[85p]

    Discussion on Treatment

    In terms of treatment methods for bodily fluids, the foremost step is to discern between deficiency and excess. If, upon examining the pulse and symptoms, it is confirmed that genuine fire causes the depletion of fluids, then simply removing the fire will allow fluids to regenerate, stopping the thirst. If the issue arises from insufficient true water, this is entirely a matter of yin deficiency, regardless of whether it pertains to the upper, middle, or lower levels. It is crucial to treat the kidneys, ensuring that the yin energy gradually replenishes and the essence and blood recover, thereby letting the illness heal naturally. If one only focuses on clearing fire, there will be no support for yin to generate, and the deterioration will be increasingly apparent, leading to more distress.

    Upper consumption leads to excessive thirst, while middle consumption results in excessive hunger. Although it is said that upper consumption pertains to the lungs and middle consumption to the stomach, fundamentally, the fire within the upper and middle burners is merely the stomach fire raging upwards. Therefore, minor distinctions in treatment are necessary. If both burners are indeed affected by excess fire, then White Tiger Decoction is appropriate for both. If there is more thirst than hunger, especially with illness predominantly in the lungs, then Ginseng White Tiger Decoction should be used. If water is deficient in the lower burner and fire is flaming in the upper burner, and there is a need to clear it, then Jade Maiden Decoction or a modified version of One-Yin Decoction should be administered.[86p]
    One says: The thirst in the upper burner is caused by the heart fire injuring the metal. It is advisable to lower the fire and clear the metal using ingredients like orchid leaves, white glossy privet flowers, yellow coptis, and anemarrhena, adding a little asarum to guide the clear qi upward and alleviate thirst. This approach can also be appropriately used.

    For the symptom of deficiency fire in the middle burner, characterized by being hungry yet thin, the ancient method directly uses formulas like the Stomach Harmonizing and Qi Regulating Decoction and San Huang Wan. However, since there is already good hunger, there should be no stagnation. If there is no stagnation, it is best to clear the fire; it is not suitable to attack the fire. Without symptoms like clumping and obstruction, using these two formulas may not be appropriate. If it is indeed due to stomach fire with no deficiency symptoms, then formulas like San Bu Wan, Yu Quan San, Bai Hu Tang, and Chou Xin Yin can all be considered for use.

    For the symptom of lower burner deficiency, where the urination is turbid like grease or oil, and there may be additional symptoms of restlessness and buzzing in the ears, this indicates depletion of kidney water. The ancient method uses formulas like Six-Flavor Rehmannia Pill to address this, which is indeed appropriate. However, from my observation, it is also necessary to distinguish between cold and heat, slick and turbid, and to treat them accordingly, so as to achieve the best outcome.[87p]
    If there is turbid urine like mucus, accompanied by heat and fire, it is advisable to supplement and also clear. One can use a formula such as Yiyin Decotion or Bunyin Pills, Dabu Yinjian, or Liuwei Dihuang Wan with Huangbai and Zhimu. If there is downward leakage and accompanying difficulty in urination, it is necessary to supplement and facilitate, primarily using formulas like Liuwei Dihuang Wan. If there is turbid urine in the lower burner with no fire, it is due to the inability of qi to contain essence, and one should focus on strengthening water and nourishing qi, using formulas like Zuo Gui Yin or Dabu Yuan Jian. If fire diminishes and cannot transform qi, and qi deficiency cannot transform fluids, one should still use formulas like You Gui Yin, You Gui Wan, or Bamei Dihuang Wan. If there is no fire in the lower burner but there is slippage, the main focus should be on consolidating the kidneys and supplementing yin, using formulas like Miyuan Jian, Gu Yin Jian, and Qinzhu Tusi Wan.

    Regarding the three types of excesses, ancients categorized the upper burner with the lungs, the middle burner with the stomach, and the lower burner with the kidneys, often treating primarily with fire, which is indeed appropriate. However, in my view, the fire of the three burner's path often has its disease rooted in the kidneys, and it is invariably related to the vital gate.[88p]
    The Gate of Life is the organ of water and fire. When there is a deficiency of water, it can certainly cause consumption and thirst; similarly, when there is a deficiency of fire, it can also lead to consumption and thirst. Why is this the case? It is because when water fails to support fire, fire cannot return to its source. Therefore, fire may wander to the lungs causing upper consumption, or to the stomach causing middle consumption, or it may consume the essence of yin causing lower consumption. These are all manifestations of true yin deficiency and indicate that water is insufficient, leading to consumption.

    Moreover, when yang fails to transform qi, water essence cannot be distributed. Water without fire cannot rise but only descend, resulting in direct entry into the bladder causing scanty urination, leading to a depletion of the springs and desiccation of the earth. This too is a manifestation of true yang deficiency, indicative of downwards fire deficiency causing consumption.

    For yin deficiency-based consumption, treatment should focus on nourishing water, as has been advised by many. However, when it comes to yang deficiency-induced consumption, people often doubt the need to replenish fire. They do not realize that adding fuel beneath a cauldron enhances the steam, that dried grains gain life from rain, and that growth returns to the peaks—these are all the workings of yang energy and represent subtle balances of life and death.

    Because consumption signs are often due to deficiency and cannot withstand excessive depletion, if one does not seek the root causes of this depletion and continues to drain the vital energy, the consumption will worsen and recovery will be impossible. Therefore, I write this again to inform the discerning.[89p]
    Secrets of the Stone Chamber
    Treatment for Diabetes

    The symptoms of diabetes, although categorized into upper, middle, and lower types, all fundamentally stem from kidney deficiency causing thirst, and there is no difference in this regard. Therefore, the primary method for treating diabetes should focus on nourishing the kidneys, without needing to distinguish between the types. I possess a particularly remarkable formula called "Combined Treatment Decoction." It consists of three taels of cooked Rehmannia, two taels each of Cornelian cherry and Ophiopogon, five qian of Plantago seeds, and one tael of Yuanshen, boiled in water and consumed daily. This will naturally cure the three types of diabetes. This formula nourishes the kidneys while also addressing excess heat. It seems suitable for those with kidney fire, but one must understand that the symptoms of diabetes cannot materialize without a fire element. I replenish water while reducing fire, allowing the excess heat to exit through the bladder while the true energy remains intact, making recovery from diabetes easier. Why complicate matters by adding more herbs like cinnamon? However, for those who have suffered long-term from diabetes and experience extreme cold in the lower body, this formula may include an additional two qian of cinnamon, if such an abnormal condition arises. If one does not follow my proportions and recklessly adjusts the ingredients, it will lead to swift death—how can one hope for survival? The symptoms of diabetes, although classified into upper, middle, and lower categories, ultimately reflect an insufficiency of kidney water. If one uses fire-clearing and thirst-quenching medications, it will further deplete the yin, inevitably augmenting the fire, which could lead to severe thirst and death. The treatment must focus on replenishing the water within the kidneys; sufficient water will naturally extinguish the fire. However, this fire is not real fire; true fire can be extinguished by cold, while虚火 (fictitious fire) must be drawn out by fire itself.[90p]
    One must also replenish the fire in the kidneys, as the fire warms the life gate; when the lower heat is addressed, the upper heat naturally resolves. This prescription is called "Fire-Attracting Yin Decoction," consisting of two taels of Yuan Shen, two qian each of cinnamon and northern five-flavor fruit, four qian of Shan Zhu Yu, one tael each of cooked earth and Mai Dong, five qian of Ba Ji Tian, all decocted in water for consumption. This formula greatly replenishes the water in the kidneys while warming the fire of the life gate, drawing the fire back to its source and allowing the fire energy to dissipate on its own. It is unnecessary to specifically quench thirst; the thirst will resolve itself, and it is not necessary to specifically subside heat; the heat will heal itself.

    For severe thirst, gypsum must be used, often accumulating to a pound over the course of a day and night. When heat is at its extreme, heavy medication is unavoidable. At this time, it is essential to avoid excessive conversation; otherwise, it could be fatal. However, this type of condition is extremely rare, occurring only once in a multitude of cases, and should not be applied indiscriminately to those with general stomach heat.

    For severe thirst, using gypsum to calm stomach heat is widely known, yet some may not understand its reason. When stomach heat surges uncontrollably, it is akin to a fire ravaging the wilderness; it requires a torrential rain to dampen and extinguish it. The use of gypsum is thus a temporary measure, often effective in the short term, but it must not be used long term as it leads to ruin.

    There is also another formula passed down as a clinical reference. For unceasing severe thirst, use several taels of gypsum, three qian of Zhi Mu, a pinched amount of glutinous rice, three taels of Mai Dong, several taels of Ren Shen, to be used alongside gypsum, with three qian of Ban Xia, one qian of Gan Cao, one hundred pieces of bamboo leaves, and two taels of Yuan Shen, all decocted in water for consumption.[91p]
