    　　一贵人病疽，疾未安而渴作，一日饮水数升，愚遂献加减地黄方。诸医大笑云：此药若能止渴，我辈当不复业医矣。皆用木瓜、紫苏、乌梅、人参、茯苓、百药煎等生津液之药止之，而渴愈甚。数剂之后，茫无功效。不得已而用前方，三日渴止。因相信久服，不特渴疾不作，气血亦壮，饮食加倍，强健过于少壮之年。盖用此药，非予敢自执鄙见，实有源流。薛氏家藏此方，屡用有验，故详着之，使有渴疾者，信其言，专志服饵取效，无为庸医所惑，庶广前人之志。久服轻身，耳目聪明，令人光泽。[68p]

    A nobleman fell ill with a disease, and while his condition had not yet stabilized, he became exceedingly thirsty. One day he drank several liters of water. Out of foolishness, I offered a modified version of the Rehmannia formula. The other doctors laughed aloud, saying, "If this medicine can quench thirst, we would no longer need to practice medicine." They all prescribed medicines like papaya, perilla, black plum, ginseng, poria, and various decoctions to generate bodily fluids, but his thirst only intensified. After several doses, there was no effect whatsoever. Reluctantly, they resorted to the previous formula, and after three days, his thirst ceased. Because of my belief in the long-term efficacy of this medicine, not only did his thirst disappear, but his vitality was also strengthened, and his appetite increased, surpassing even his youth. This usage of the medicine is not just based on my narrow view; it indeed has historical roots. The Xue family has preserved this formula, having used it with verified results multiple times. Hence, I detail it here so that those suffering from thirst can trust its efficacy, dedicatedly use the medicine, and not be misled by mediocre doctors, thereby expanding upon the wisdom of our predecessors. Long-term use lightens the body, sharpens the senses, and brings luminosity to one's appearance.[68p]

    盖内北五味最为得力，独能补肾水，平补降心气。其肉桂一味不可废，若去肉桂，服亦不应。　　一男子患此，欲治以前丸，彼谓肉桂性热，乃易黄蘗、知母等药。渴不止，发背疽而殁。夫肉桂，肾经药也。前证乃肾经虚火炎上，无制为患，用桂导引诸药以补之，及引虚火归元，故效。成无己云：桂尤圭也，引导阳气，若执以使。　　若夫上消者，谓心移热于肺；中消者，谓内虚胃热。皆认火热为害，故或以白虎，或以承气，卒致不救。[69p]

    The five flavors mainly found in the north are particularly effective, especially for replenishing kidney water and calming the fiery energy of the heart. Among these, the herb cinnamon must not be neglected; if it is removed, the remedy will be ineffective.

    A man suffering from this condition attempted to treat it with a previous formula but replaced cinnamon with drugs such as coptis and anemarrhena, believing that cinnamon is too warming. He remained relentlessly thirsty, developed back sores, and ultimately died. Indeed, cinnamon is a medicinal ingredient for the kidney channel. The previous signs indicated a deficiency of kidney fire rising upwards, which, without proper regulation, became harmful; thus, cinnamon was used to guide other medicines to nourish and redirect the deficient fire back to its source, leading to its efficacy. Cheng Wujin states: Cinnamon is particularly guiding, aiding in directing yang energy, like a harness that leads the flow.

    As for the issue of upward consumption, it refers to heat from the heart moving into the lungs; and for middle consumption, it refers to internal deficiencies causing stomach heat. All recognize heat as harmful, which leads to the use of formulas like Bai Hu or Cheng Qi, ultimately resulting in failure to save the patient.[69p]

    总之是下焦命门，火不归元，游于肺则为上消，游于胃即为中消，以八味肾气丸引火归元，使火在釜底，水火既济，气上熏蒸，肺受湿气而渴疾愈矣。　　有一等渴欲引饮，但饮水不过一二口即厌，少顷复渴，饮亦不过若此，但不若消渴者饮水无厌也。此是中气虚寒，寒水泛上，逼其浮游之火，于咽喉口舌之间，故上焦一段，欲得水救，若到中焦，以水见水，正其所恶也。治法：如面红烦躁者，理中汤送八味丸。　　又有一等渴欲饮水，但饮下少顷即吐出，吐出少顷复求饮，药食毫不能下，此是阴盛格阳，肾经伤寒之证。仲景以白通加人尿、胆汁，热药冷探之法，一服即愈。女人多有此证。[70p]

    In summary, this concerns the lower burner and the vital gate; when the fire does not return to its origin and wanders in the lungs, it results in upper depletion; when it wanders in the stomach, it results in middle depletion. Using the Eight Flavor Kidney Qi Pill to draw the fire back to its origin allows the fire to settle at the bottom of the cauldron, balancing water and fire. When the Qi rises and steams, the lungs suffer from dampness, leading to thirst and illness recovery.

    There is a type of thirst that seeks to drink, but the person quickly becomes weary after just one or two sips of water, soon feeling thirsty again. They can only drink a little, unlike those with true thirst who drink without limit. This indicates a deficiency of middle Qi and coldness, where cold water rises to push against the wandering fire in the throat and tongue; hence, the upper burner craves water for relief. However, reaching the middle burner, the water encounters water and intensifies what is undesirable. Treatment: if the face is red and the person is agitated, administer the Li Zhong Decoction together with the Eight Flavor Pill.

    Another type of thirst involves wanting to drink water but immediately vomits it back up after swallowing; shortly after, the person seeks more to drink but can hardly take in any food or medicine. This indicates an excess of yin obstructing yang, a sign of kidney channel injury due to cold. Zhang Zhongjing added human urine and bile to the Bai Tong formula, utilizing hot medicine with a cold exploration method; a single dose can lead to recovery. Many women experience this condition.[70p]

    　　　　医门法律 【清　喻昌】

    　　　　　消渴论

    　　消渴之患，常始于微而成于着，始于胃而极于肺肾。始如以水沃焦，水入犹能消之；既而以水投石，水去而石自若。至于饮一溲一，饮一溲二，则燥火劫其真阴，操立尽之术，而势成熇熇矣。《内经》有其论无其治，《金匮》有论有治矣。而集书者，采《伤寒论》厥阴经消渴之文凑入，后人不能决择，斯亦不适于用也。盖伤寒传经，热邪至厥阴而尽，热势入深，故渴而消水，及热解则不渴且不消矣，岂杂证积渐为患之比乎？谨从《内经》拟议言之。经谓凡治消瘅、仆击、偏枯、痿厥、气满发逆，肥贵人则膏粱之疾也，此中消所由来也。肥而不贵，食弗给于鲜。贵而不肥，餐弗过于饕。[71p]

    Discussion on Thirst and Consumption

    The affliction of thirst often begins subtly and becomes pronounced, starting in the stomach and culminating in the lungs and kidneys. At first, it is like watering a burning fire; water can still extinguish it. But later, it becomes like pouring water on a stone; when the water is gone, the stone remains unchanged. When drinking and urinating becomes frequent, it consumes the true yin with dryness and fire, leading to exhaustion. According to the "Inner Canon," there are discussions but no treatments. The "Golden Chamber" contains both discussions and treatments. However, compilers have conflated the discussions in "Treatise on Cold Damage" concerning the Throat Meridian's thirst, leading later generations to be unable to distinguish appropriateness, which is also unsuitable for application. The transmission of cold damage indicates that when the heat pathogen reaches the Throat Meridian, it is entirely manifested; when heat penetrates deeply, thirst arises and consumption occurs. Once the heat resolves, there is no thirst and no consumption. Is this comparable to conditions arising from accumulated symptoms? I humbly propose a discussion based on the "Inner Canon." The texts say that in treating conditions like consumption, collapse, atrophy, weakness, and rebellious qi in the abdomen, afflictions among the wealthy are due to rich foods, which are the sources of consumption. The wealthy who are not overweight may lack fresh food, while the overweight who are not wealthy might overindulge.[71p]

    肥而且贵，醇酒厚味，熟为限量哉？久之，食饮酿成内热，津液干涸，求济于水。然水入尚能消之也，愈消愈渴，其膏粱愈无已，而中消之病遂成矣。夫既瘅成为中消，随其或上或下，火热炽盛之区，以次传入矣。上消者，胃以其热，上输于肺，而子受母累。心复以其热，移之于肺，而金受火刑。金者，生水而出高源者也。饮入胃中，游溢精气而上，则肺通调水道而下，今火热入之，高源之水为暴虐所逼，合外饮之水，建瓴而下，饮一溲二，不但不能消外水，且并素蕴水精，竭绝而尽输于下，较大腑之暴注暴泄，尤为甚矣。故死不治也。所谓由心之肺谓之死阴，死阴之属，不过三日而死者，此之谓也。故饮一溲二，第一危候也。[72p]

    Fatty and expensive, rich wine with thick flavor—are these limited in quantity? Over time, consuming them generates internal heat, and bodily fluids dry up, leading one to seek relief from water. However, when water enters, it can still alleviate this, but the more it alleviates, the thirstier one becomes. The richer the food consumed, the worse the inner heat becomes, leading to the illness of internal consumption. Once this internal consumption manifests, it transmits through various pathways, whether upward or downward, especially in areas of intense heat.

    Upper consumption occurs when the stomach, heated, affects the lungs, burdening the body. The heart, also heated, transfers this heat to the lungs, resulting in suffering for the metal (lungs). Metal is the source of water that emerges from higher origins. When consumed in the stomach, the essence overflows and rises, the lungs adjust the water pathways downward. Now, when heated, the water from the high source is violently pressured, mixing with externally consumed water, rushing down uncontrollably. Urinating often does not merely fail to eliminate external water, but also exhausts and drains the essence of innate water, leading to significant excess in waste discharge.

    Therefore, without treatment, one dies. The so-called "death of yin" related to the heart and lungs, where death can occur within three days, refers to this. Thus, urinating often—first sign of danger.[72p]

    至于胃以其热由关门下传于肾，肾或以石药耗其真，女谒竭其精者，阳强于外，阴不内守，而小溲浑浊如膏，饮一溲一，肾消之证成矣。经谓石药之性悍，又谓脾风传之肾名曰疝瘕，少腹冤热而痛，出白液，名曰蛊。明指肾消为言。医和有云：女子阳物也，晦淫则生内热惑蛊之疾。此解冤热及蛊义甚明。王太仆谓：消烁肌肉，如蛊之蚀，日渐损削，乃从消字起见，浅矣浅矣。夫惑女色以丧志，精泄无度，以至水液浑浊，反从火化，亦最危候。经云：君火之下，阴精承之。故阴精有余，足以上承心火，则其人寿；阴精不足，心火直下肾中，阳精所降，其人夭矣。故肾者胃之关也，关门不开则水无输泄而为肿满，关门不闭则水无底止而为消渴。消渴属肾一证，《金匮》原文未脱，其曰饮一斗，溲一斗者，肾气丸主之。[73p]

    As for the stomach, its heat is transmitted down through the gate to the kidneys. The kidneys may be depleted by stone medicine, exhausting their essence. When a woman experiences this, yang is strong externally, while yin cannot maintain itself internally. This leads to cloudy urination like sludge; after drinking, urination occurs frequently, indicating kidney depletion. The classics mention that the nature of stone medicine is harsh, and it is said that the wind from the spleen transmits to the kidneys, causing what is known as hernia and distension, with pain in the lower abdomen and the discharge of white fluid, referred to as "gu." This clearly indicates kidney depletion.

    A physician named He states: Women possess yang; indulgence leads to internal heat and the affliction of "gu." This elaboration on internal heat and the meaning of "gu" is quite clear. The Grand Minister Wang said: Depletion consumes the flesh like "gu" erodes. This is clearly evident from the term "depletion," which is rather shallow. Indeed, being obsessed with women's beauty results in loss of will, and excessive loss of essence leads to turbid fluids, transforming back into a fire, which is the most perilous condition. The classics state: "When the ruler's fire descends, yin essence supports it." Therefore, if there is an excess of yin essence, it is sufficient to support heart fire, signifying longevity; if yin essence is insufficient, heart fire will descend directly to the kidneys, leading to a decline in yang essence, resulting in premature death.

    Thus, the kidneys serve as the gate of the stomach; if the gate lacks openness, water cannot be released and leads to swelling. If the gate is not closed, water is unceasingly expelled, resulting in thirst. Thirst is a condition belonging to the kidneys; the original text of "Jin Kui" remains unaltered, stating that when one drinks a dou, they urinate a dou, which is governed by kidney qi.[73p]

    于是蒸动精水，上承君火，而止其下入之阳光，此正通天手眼，张子和辄敢诋之。既诋仲景，复谀河间，谓其神芎丸以黄芩味苦入心，牵牛大黄驱火气而下，以滑石引入肾经，将离入坎，真得黄庭之秘。颠倒其说，阿私所好，识趣卑陋若此，又何足以入仲景之门哉？何柏斋《消渴论》中，已辨其非。昌观戴人吐下诸案中，从无有治消渴一案者，可见无其事即无其理矣。篇首论火一段，非不有其理也。然以承气治壮火之理施之，消渴又无其事矣。故下消之火，水中之火也，下之则愈燔。中消之火，竭泽之火也，下之则愈伤。上消之火，燎原之火也，水从天降可灭。徒攻肠胃，无益反损。夫地气上为云，然后天气下为雨，是故雨出地气。地气不上，天能雨乎？故亟升地气以慰三农，与亟升肾气以溉三焦，皆事理之必然者耳。不与昔贤一为分辨，后人亦安能行其所明哉？[74p]

    Then steam transforms essence into water, ascending to receive the fire of the ruler, while halting the lower entry of the Yang energy. This is the true communication between heaven and earth. Zhang Zihe dared to disparage it. After denigrating Zhongjing, he praised Hejian, claiming its Shenxiong pill, made with the bitter taste of Huangqin, enters the heart, while Qianniu and Dahuang drive down the fire energy, using Shalstone to channel into the kidney meridian, effectively taking it away from the Kan. This truly grasps the secret of the Huangting. He twists this doctrine to cater to his own preferences, with a shallow understanding that is hardly worthy to enter Zhongjing’s door. He Bai's "Treatise on Diabetes" has already clarified its errors. Chang Guan's accounts have never treated diabetes, proving that without the issue, there can be no reasoning behind it. The discussion on fire at the beginning is not without its reason. However, applying the principle of purging Qi to treat vigorous fire leads to no effective result for diabetes. Thus, the fire of below diabetes is akin to fire in water; lowering it only intensifies the burn. The fire of middle diabetes is akin to the draining fire of marshes; lowering it only causes more harm. The fire of upper diabetes is like a wildfire; water that falls from heaven can extinguish it. Merely attacking the intestines and stomach is of no benefit, and instead causes harm. The earth's energy rises as clouds, and in turn, the heavens’ energy descends as rain; thus, rain arises from the earth's energy. If the earth’s energy does not rise, can the heavens rain? Therefore, it is imperative to elevate the earth's energy to nourish the three farmers, as well as to elevate the kidney's energy to irrigate the three burners—both are necessary truths. Not distinguishing this from the ancients, how can later generations adhere to what is clear?[74p]

    　　　　　续论

    　　昌着消渴论，聊会《内经》大意，谓始于胃而极于肺肾，定为中上下之三消。其他膈消、食(亻亦)等证，要亦中上之消耳。然未得《金匮》之实据，心恒不慊。越二岁，忽忆《内经》云：有所劳倦，形气衰少，谷气不盛，上焦不行，胃气热，热气熏胸中，故内热。恍然悟胸中受病消息，唯是胃中水谷之气，与胸中天真灌注环周，乃得清明在躬。[75p]

    Continuation of the Discussion

    In "On Thirst," Chang discusses the essence of the "Inner Canon," stating that it begins in the stomach and culminates in the lungs and kidneys, defining the three areas of consumption as being upper and middle. Other conditions like diaphragm consumption and food-related issues are also just forms of upper and middle consumption. However, without practical references from the "Essential Prescription," my heart remained unsatisfied. Two years later, I suddenly remembered the "Inner Canon" stating: when there is labor and fatigue, the physical energy diminishes, and the energy of grains is not abundant. The upper burner does not function well, the stomach's energy is hot, and this heat disturbs the chest, resulting in internal heat. I realized that the disease in the chest is solely due to the energy of food and grain in the stomach, which circulates and nourishes the chest, allowing for clarity and brightness to manifest in one's own body.[75p]

    若有所劳倦，伤其大气宗气，则胸中之气衰少，胃中谷气因而不盛，谷气不盛，胸中所伤之气，愈益难复，而不能以充行，于是谷气留于胃中，胃中郁而为热，热气熏入胸中，混合其衰少之气，变为内热，胸胃间不觉易其冲和之旧矣，求其不消不渴宁可得乎？透此一关，读《金匮》所不了了者，今始明之。其云：寸口脉浮而迟，浮即为虚，数即为劳，虚则卫气不足，劳则荣气竭；趺阳脉浮而数，浮则为气，数则消谷而大坚，气盛则溲数，溲数则坚，坚数相搏，即为消渴。举寸口以候胸中之气，举趺阳以候胃中之气，显然有脉之可循，显然有证之可察，然且难解其微焉。盖阴在内，为阳之守；阳在外，为阴之固。寸口脉浮，阴不内守，故外卫之阳浮即为虚也；寸口脉迟，阳不外固，故内守之阴迟即为劳也。总因劳伤荣卫，致寸口脉虚而迟也。然营者水谷之精气，卫者水谷之悍气，虚而且迟，水谷之气不上充而内郁，已见膈虚胃热之一斑矣。[76p]

    If there is fatigue or weariness that harms the fundamental energy and vital essence, then the energy in the chest becomes weak; the digestive energy in the stomach thereby does not thrive. When the digestive energy does not thrive, the injured energy in the chest becomes even harder to recover, and cannot be adequately replenished. Consequently, the digestive energy remains stagnant in the stomach, causing stagnation and heat within. This heat then pervades the chest, mixing with the weakened energy and transforming into internal heat. The balance between the chest and stomach becomes unsettled, making it impossible to avoid thirst and depletion.

    Understanding this key point clarifies what has been previously misunderstood in the "Golden Chamber" text. It states: if the pulse at the wrist is floating and slow, the floating indicates deficiency, and the slow indicates fatigue. Deficiency implies insufficient protective energy, and fatigue means that the nourishing energy is depleted. If the pulse at the foot is floating and rapid, the floating signifies energy, and the rapid indicates that the digestive process is impaired and there is excessive solidity; abundant energy results in quick urination, and quick urination indicates solidity. When solidity and rapidity collide, this signifies thirst.

    By examining the wrist pulse, one can assess the energy in the chest; by examining the pulse at the foot, one can assess the energy in the stomach. Clearly, there is a pulse to follow and evident signs to observe, yet it is difficult to discern the subtleties. The essence lies in the fact that yin resides within, safeguarding the yang; yang is outside, reinforcing the yin. A floating pulse at the wrist indicates that yin is not properly maintaining itself internally, thus, the yang in the external protective layer is floating and signifies deficiency. A slow pulse at the wrist indicates that yang is not effectively anchored externally, therefore, the yin safeguarding internally is slow and signifies fatigue. Overall, it is the injury of nourishing and protective energies that causes the wrist pulse to be deficient and slow. The nourishing energy pertains to the essence of food and water, while the protective energy pertains to their robust qualities. When both are deficient and slow, the energy from food and water fails to rise and fills the interior with stagnation, which is already evident of a weak diaphragm and stomach heat.[76p]

    更参以趺阳脉之浮数，浮则为气，即《内经》热气熏胸中之变文，数则消谷而大坚。昌前论中既如以水投石，水去而石自若，偶合胃中大坚，消谷不消水之象，可见火热本足消水也，水入本足救渴也。胃中坚燥，全不受水之浸润，转从火热之势，急奔膀胱，故溲数。溲去其内愈燥，所以坚数相搏，即为消渴。直引《内经》味过于苦，久从火化，脾气不濡，胃气乃厚之意，为消渴之源，精矣微矣。晋唐以后，代不乏贤，随其聪敏，揣摩《内经》，各自名家，卒皆不入仲景堂奥，其所得于《内经》者浅耳。使深则能随证比类，各出脉证方治，以昭成法，而《金匮》遗编，家传户诵之矣。[77p]

    In addition to the floating pulse of the Fuyang meridian, when it is floating it represents Qi, which corresponds to the changes described in the "Inner Canon" regarding heat Qi scorching the chest; when it is rapid, it indicates the consumption of food and the presence of a large hardness. In the earlier discussion, it is like water being poured over a stone: when the water is gone, the stone remains unchanged. This coincides with the presence of hardness in the stomach, where food is consumed but water is not, illustrating that the heat of fire can consume water, while water can quench thirst. When the stomach is hard and dry, it does not absorb water; instead, it is driven by the force of heat, leading to rapid urination, resulting in frequent urination. This depletion exacerbates dryness, thus the hardness and frequency clash, constituting thirst. Directly referencing the "Inner Canon," excessive bitterness, prolonged exposure to heat transforms it, and the spleen's Qi is not moistened, leading to a thickened stomach Qi — this is the source of thirst, both subtle and significant. After the Jin and Tang dynasties, while there were many who were wise and insightful, interpreting the "Inner Canon," each rising figure became notable in their own right, yet none entered the profound teachings of Zhang Zhongjing, as what they obtained from the "Inner Canon" was shallow. Had they delved deeper, they could have correlated conditions, compared symptoms, and derived treatments based on pulse and symptomology to clarify established methods, but the remnants of the "Golden Cabinet" have been passed down and recited in households.[77p]

    即如消渴证，相沿谓中消者宜下之，共守一语，更无别商，岂一下可了其局乎？抑陆续徐下之乎？夫胃已大坚，不受膏沐，辄投承气，坚者不受瑕者受之矣，膀胱不受大肠受之矣，岂不乘其药势，传为利下鹜溏中满肿胀之证乎？《总录》谓：末传能食者必发脑疽背疮，不能食者必传中满鼓胀，皆为不治之证。诸家不亟亟于始传中传，反于末传，多方疗治，如忍冬、蓝叶、荠苨丸散，及紫苏、葶苈中满分消汤丸，欲何为耶？《金匮》于小溲微觉不利，早用文蛤一味治之，方书从不录用。讵知软坚之品，非劫阴即伤阴，独此一种，平善无过，兼可利水，诚足宝乎！洁古谓：能食而渴者，白虎加人参汤。不能食而渴者，钱氏白朮散加葛根。末传疮疽者，火邪盛也，急攻其阳，无攻其阴。下焦元气，得强者生，失强者死。[78p]

    Just as in cases of thirst, it is traditionally said that those with mid-thirst should be treated with purgatives, adhering to this principle without other considerations. Can one resolve the issue with just one treatment? Or should it be approached progressively? The stomach has become large and firm and does not accept nourishment easily; just administering purgatives may not yield results. The firm does not respond, while the weak does. The bladder does not act, but the large intestine does; could this not lead to complications driven by the medication, resulting in issues like fullness and swelling? The "Comprehensive Record" states: those who are able to eat but develop boils will inevitably suffer from severe swelling; those who cannot eat will certainly experience abdominal fullness and bloating, all of which are signs of an illness that cannot be treated. Various schools do not focus on the initial stages of the disease but rather on the later stages, employing many treatments like honeysuckle, blue leaves, and herbal pills, as well as combinations for abdominal fullness. What is their intention? The "Golden Cabinet" suggests that in instances of slight urinary discomfort, one should early on use only clam as treatment, which is not mentioned in published formulas. Little do they know that softening and firming substances, if not treating deficiency can injure it, while this particular one is benign, effective for diuresis, and truly precious! Jiegao states: for those who can eat but are thirsty, one should use White Tiger Decoctio with ginseng. For those who cannot eat but are thirsty, one should use the Qian family's white atractylodes powder with kudzu root. The late-stage boils are a result of excessive fire; one must urgently attack the Yang, not the Yin. The fundamental qi of the lower region: if strengthened, life arises; if weakened, death ensues.[78p]

    末传中满者，高消中消制之太过，速过病所，上热未除，中寒复起，非药之罪，用药时失其缓急之制也。洁古老人可谓空谷足音矣。所云无攻其阴，得强者生，失强者死，皆虑泉竭之微言，令人耸然起敬。于是追步后尘，徐商一语曰：三消总为火病，岂待末传疮疽，始为火邪胜耶？然火之在阳在阴，分何脏腑，合何脏腑，宜升宜降，宜折宜伏，各各不同，从其性而治之，使不相扞格，乃为良法。若不治其火，但治其热，火无所归，热宁有止耶？如肾消，阴病用六味丸，阳病用八味丸，此亦一法。若谓下消只此一法，其去中消宜下之说能以寸哉！　　《内经》阴阳别论曰：二阳结谓之消。[79p]

    The text discusses the medical philosophy regarding the treatment of illnesses associated with excess heat and cold in the body. It emphasizes the importance of understanding the nature of the illness and the appropriate treatment methods. It criticizes rushing to use remedies without considering their effects on the body. The reference to the "pure ancient elder" suggests a reverence for traditional wisdom, particularly in avoiding aggressive treatments that could worsen a patient's condition. The mention of the three types of wasting diseases (消) relates to fire pathology, arguing that one must recognize how heat impacts different organs and should treat accordingly. It warns against merely addressing symptoms without understanding the root causes, illustrating the complexity of balancing yin and yang within the body. This balance is crucial in effective healing methods, and the text concludes by referencing the "Inner Canon" which classifies illnesses related to the emergence of excess yang as wasting diseases.[79p]

    二阳者，阳明也。手阳明大肠主津，病消则目黄口干，是津不足也。足阳明胃主血，病热则消谷善饥，血中伏火、乃血不足也。结者津血不足，结而不行，皆燥之为病也。　　《内经》曰：心移热于肺，传为膈消。张子和谓膈消犹未及于肺，至心移寒于肺，乃为肺消，如此泥文害意，非能读《内经》者也。岂有心移热于肺，肺传其热于膈，犹未及肺之理？必变经文为心移热于膈，传为肺消，乃不泥乎？要识心肺同居膈上，肺为娇脏，移寒移热，总之易入，但寒邪入而外束，热邪入而外传，均一肺梢，而治则有分矣。　　刘河间论三消之疾，本湿寒之阴气极衰，燥热之阳气太甚，六气中已遗风火二气矣。[80p]

    The "two Yangs" refers to the Yangming. The Yangming of the hand rules the large intestine and governs fluids; when disease leads to deficiency, one experiences yellowing of the eyes and dryness of the mouth, indicating insufficient fluids. The Yangming of the foot governs the stomach and rules the blood; when disease is hot, there is a tendency for excessive hunger and a lurking fire in the blood, indicating insufficient blood. A blockage arises from a lack of fluids and blood; when blocked and not moving, it is a disease caused by dryness.

    The "Neijing" states: the heart transfers heat to the lungs, which results in diaphragm dysfunction. Zhang Zihe suggests that diaphragm dysfunction has not yet reached the lungs; when the heart transfers cold to the lungs, this constitutes lung dysfunction. By muddying the text, one misunderstands the "Neijing." How could it be that the heart transfers heat to the lungs, and the lungs pass that heat to the diaphragm, but it has not yet affected the lungs? It is necessary to change the text to state that the heart transfers heat to the diaphragm, which then transmits it to the lungs, thereby avoiding confusion.

    It must be understood that the heart and lungs both reside above the diaphragm, with the lungs being a delicate organ. Cold and heat can easily enter; however, when cold pathogens enter, they are bound externally, while hot pathogens enter and transmit outward. Both affect the lung tips, but treatment must differentiate them.

    Liu Hejian discussed the disease of the "three consumptions," attributing it to extreme depletion of the cold-deficient yin and excessive surplus of the hot-strong yang, leaving out the elements of wind and fire from the six influences.[80p]

    且以消渴、消中、消肾，分名三消，岂中下二消，无渴可言耶？及引经言有心肺气厥而渴，有肝痹而渴，有痹热而渴，有胃与大肠结热而渴，有脾痹而渴，有肾热而渴，有小肠痹热而渴，愈推愈泛，其不合论消渴，但举渴之一端，为燥热亡液之验，诚不可解。《玉机微义》深取其说，发暖药补肾之误，吾不知暖药果为何药也。世岂有以暖药治消渴之理哉？其意盖在非《金匮》之主肾气丸耳。夫肾气丸蒸动肾水，为治消渴之圣药，后世咸知之，而何柏斋复辨之。昌恐后学偶阅子和、宗厚之说，反滋疑眩，故再陈之。　　瘅成为消中，胃热极深，胃火极炽，以故能食易饥多渴，诸家咸谓宜用大承气汤下之矣。不知积渐之热，素蕴之火，无取急下，下之亦不去，徒伤肠胃，转增其困耳。[81p]

    The conditions known as "Three Privations"—namely, consuming thirst, consuming in the middle, and consuming of the kidneys—are categorized as such. Can there truly be a consumption of the middle and lower without thirst? It is stated in the texts that thirst can arise from various causes: heart and lung qi stagnation leading to thirst, liver blockage causing thirst, heat obstruction leading to thirst, stomach and large intestine heat causing thirst, spleen blockage resulting in thirst, kidney heat causing thirst, and small intestine heat causing thirst. The more one examines these causes, the more one finds them lacking in clarity regarding consuming thirst, merely citing thirst as a manifestation of dryness and heat depleting fluids, which is indeed puzzling.

    In the "Essentials of the Jade Mechanism," there is a deep discussion on this, erroneously attributing the cure for consumption to warming remedies for the kidneys; I am unsure what such warming medicines truly entail. Is there any reasoning in the world that a warming remedy could treat consuming thirst? The implication likely lies in the fact that it is not based on the "Golden Cabinet" principle of Kidney Qi Pills. Yet Kidney Qi Pills invigorate kidney water and are known as the miraculous remedy for consuming thirst, recognized by later generations. Why then does Bai Zhai further elaborate on this?

    I am concerned that later scholars might casually come across the discussions of Zi He and Zong Hou, which might confuse and mislead them further, prompting me to restate this point. The condition called "Dampness" leads to consuming in the middle, with intense stomach heat and excessive stomach fire, resulting in an increased appetite and thirst. Various schools suggest the use of Major Decoction to Purge for treatment. However, they fail to recognize that the accumulated heat, which has gradually developed, and the inherent fire will not be resolved by aggressive purging. Merely purging will be harmful to the intestines and stomach and will worsen the discomfort.[81p]

    故不得已而用大黄，当久蒸以和其性，更不可合枳实、厚朴同用，助其疾趋之势。洁古用本方更其名曰顺利散，隐然取顺利不取攻劫之意。方下云：治中消热在胃而能食，小便赤黄微利，至不欲食为效，不可多利。昌恐微利至不欲食，胃气已不存矣。承气非微利之法而可渎用乎？子和更其方为加减三黄丸，合大黄、芩、连用之，不用枳、朴矣。方下云：治丹石毒及热渴。以意测度，须大实者方用，曾不思消渴证真气为热火所耗，几见有大实之人耶？然则欲除胃中火热，必如之何而后可？昌谓久蒸大黄，与甘草合用则急缓互调，与人参合用则攻补兼施，如充国之屯田金城，坐困先零，庶几可图三年之艾。目前纵有乘机斗捷之着，在所不举，如之何欲取效眉睫耶？昔贤过矣。　　律五条[82p]

    Therefore, when necessary to use rhubarb, it must be long steamed to harmonize its properties. Moreover, it should not be combined with bitter orange or amomum, as this would exacerbate the urgency of the illness. The ancient remedy known as "Shunli Powder" implies a gentle approach, avoiding aggression.

    The formula states: for treating internal heat in the stomach that affects appetite, with slight yellowish red urine and minimal urination, if one loses the desire to eat, it should not be overutilized. I fear that minimal urination leading to loss of appetite indicates that the stomach qi is already depleted. The method of purging medicine is not to be recklessly applied.

    You harmonize this formula into "Jiajian Sanyuan Pill," combining rhubarb with Scutellaria and Coptis, while not using bitter orange or amomum. The formula also addresses the toxicity and heat caused by mineral medications. By intuition, it must be used with substantial effectiveness, considering whether the condition of dryness is due to the body's genuine qi being consumed by excessive heat. Is there truly anyone of substantial build?

    Thus, to eliminate the heat from the stomach, what must be done? I believe that prolonged steaming of rhubarb, combined with licorice, can provide a balanced approach to quickening and soothing. When used with ginseng, it can simultaneously attack and tonify, similar to enhancing agricultural production in a prosperous land, enduring initial challenges, thereby hoping for benefits over three years. Currently, even if there are opportunities for quick gains, they should not be pursued, as how could one expect immediate results? The ancient sages have surpassed this understanding.[82p]

    　　凡治初得消渴病，不急生津补水，降火彻热，用药无当，迁延误人，医之罪也。　　凡治中消病成，不急救金水二脏，泉之竭矣，不云自中，医之罪也。　　凡治肺消病，而以地黄丸治其血分，肾消病而以白虎汤治其气分，执一不通，病不能除，医之罪也。　　凡消渴病少愈，不急回枯泽槁，听其土燥不生，致酿疮疽无救，医之罪也。　　门冬饮子易老　治老弱虚人大渴。[83p]

    When treating initial stages of thirst disease, one should not hastily produce fluids to replenish water or lower heat. Inadequate use of medicine prolongs suffering, which is the physician's fault.

    When treating middle stage of thirst disease, one should not urgently revive the organs tied to metal and water; when the source is exhausted and there are no signs of recovery, this is the physician's fault.

    When treating pulmonary thirst disease, using dihuang pills for blood issues, or using Baihu decoction for kidney issues, if one adheres to a single approach without addressing the whole, the illness cannot be resolved, which is the physician's fault.

    If thirst disease shows little improvement, one should not hastily return to dry and parched conditions, ignoring that the soil is dry and unproductive, leading to the brewing of sores and abscesses without remedy, which is the physician's fault.

    The "Mendong Drink" is suitable for elderly and weak individuals suffering from excessive thirst.[83p]

    　　凡治消渴病，用寒凉太过，乃至水胜火湮，犹不知反，渐成肿满不救，医之罪也。
    　　　　景岳全书 【明　张介宾】

    　　　　　论证

    　　三消之病，三焦受病也。上消者，渴证也，大渴引饮，随饮随渴，以上焦之津液枯涸，古云其病在肺，而不知心脾阳明之火，皆能熏炙而然，故又谓之膈消也。　　中消者，中焦病也，多食善饥，不为肌肉而日加削瘦，其病在脾胃，又谓之消中也。　　下消者，下焦病也，小便黄赤，为淋为浊，如膏如脂，面黑耳焦，日渐消瘦，其病在肾，故又名肾消也。此三消者，古人悉认为火证，然有实火者，以邪热有余也；有虚火者，以真阴不足也。使治消证而不辨虚实，则未有不误者矣。　　消证有阴阳，尤不可不察。如多渴者曰消渴，善饥者曰消谷，小便淋浊如膏者曰肾消。[84p]

    In treating diabetes, excessive use of cold and cool treatments can overwhelm the body's fire, even leading to water overpowering fire—a failure to recognize this can result in swelling and fullness beyond recovery, which is the fault of the physician.

    The illness of the three types of diabetes is related to the three burners. The upper diabetes, characterized by extreme thirst, leads to constant drinking; this depletes the fluids in the upper burner. It has been said that the disease lies in the lungs, yet it is also due to the heat from the heart and spleen, which can scorch these areas, hence it is also called phlegm diabetes. The middle diabetes pertains to the middle burner, where excessive eating leads to hunger without increasing flesh, resulting in gradual weight loss; this disease is located in the spleen and stomach, also referred to as ingestion diabetes. The lower diabetes concerns the lower burner, where urine is yellow and turbid, sometimes resembling fat or grease, with the face dark and ears scorched, involving gradual weight loss; this ailment is in the kidneys, thus also known as kidney diabetes.

    The ancients recognized all three types as manifestations of fire disease, yet there are cases of real fire caused by excess heat, and instances of false fire from insufficient true yin. If one treats diabetes without distinguishing between excess and deficiency, errors are inevitable. Understanding the distinctions of yin and yang in diabetes is crucial. For example, excessive thirst is termed "thirst diabetes," excessive hunger is termed "grain diabetes," and turbid urine resembling fat indicates "kidney diabetes."[84p]

    凡此者，多由于火盛则阴虚，是皆阳消之证也。至于阴消之义，则未有知之者。盖消者，消烁也，亦消耗也。凡阴阳血气之属，日见消败者，皆谓之消，故不可尽以火证为言。何以见之？如气厥论曰：心移寒于肺为肺消，饮一溲二，死不治。此正以元气之衰，而金寒水冷，故水不化气，而气悉化水，岂非阳虚之阴证乎？又如邪气脏腑病形篇言：五脏之脉细小者皆为消瘅。岂以微小之脉而为有余之阳证乎？此《内经》阴消之义，固已显然言之，而但人所未审耳。故凡治三消证者，必当察其脉气病气形气，但见本元亏损，及假火等证，必当速救根本以资化源。若但知为火而专务清理，未有不阴阳俱败者矣。[85p]

    All of this arises mainly because a strong fire leads to a deficiency of yin, which is a sign of the consumption of yang. However, the meaning of yin consumption is not well understood by many. Consumption refers to both dissolution and depletion. Any decline and failure of the yin-yang, blood, or qi is termed consumption, so one cannot entirely explain it in terms of fire. How can this be demonstrated? For instance, the theory of qi collapse states: "When the heart is influenced by cold in the lungs, it leads to lung consumption; after drinking one or two urinations, death occurs without treatment." This is precisely due to the decline of foundational qi, leading to coldness in metal and water; thus, water fails to transform into qi, while all qi transforms into water. Isn't this a manifestation of yin deficiency presenting as a sign of yang? Furthermore, the chapter on pathogenic influences in organs says: "When the pulses of the five organs are thin and small, it signifies consumption and stagnation." Can one consider these thin pulses as signs of excess yang? This clearly illustrates the concept of yin consumption in the "Inner Classic," which is not well comprehended by people. Therefore, when treating the three signs of consumption, one must observe the pulses and the nature of the disease. If one only notes the deficiency of foundational qi and associated signs of false heat, they must swiftly address the root cause to nourish the source of transformation. Merely recognizing the condition as fire and focusing on clearing it will inevitably result in both yin and yang failing.[85p]

    　　　　　论治

    　　凡治消之法，最当先辨虚实。若察其脉证，果为实火致耗津液者，但去其火，则津液自生而消渴自止。若由真水不足，则悉属阴虚，无论上中下，急宜治肾，必使阴气渐充，精血渐复，则病必自愈。若但知清火，则阴无以生，而日见消败，益以困矣。　　上消善渴，中消善饥。虽曰上消属肺，中消属胃，然总之火在上中二焦者，亦无非胃火上炎而然，但当微为分别以治之。若二焦果由实火，则皆宜白虎汤主之。若渴多饥少，病多在肺者，宜人参白虎汤主之。若水亏于下，火炎于上，有不得不清者，宜玉女煎或加减一阴煎之类主之。[86p]

    Discussion on Treatment

    In terms of treatment methods for bodily fluids, the foremost step is to discern between deficiency and excess. If, upon examining the pulse and symptoms, it is confirmed that genuine fire causes the depletion of fluids, then simply removing the fire will allow fluids to regenerate, stopping the thirst. If the issue arises from insufficient true water, this is entirely a matter of yin deficiency, regardless of whether it pertains to the upper, middle, or lower levels. It is crucial to treat the kidneys, ensuring that the yin energy gradually replenishes and the essence and blood recover, thereby letting the illness heal naturally. If one only focuses on clearing fire, there will be no support for yin to generate, and the deterioration will be increasingly apparent, leading to more distress.

    Upper consumption leads to excessive thirst, while middle consumption results in excessive hunger. Although it is said that upper consumption pertains to the lungs and middle consumption to the stomach, fundamentally, the fire within the upper and middle burners is merely the stomach fire raging upwards. Therefore, minor distinctions in treatment are necessary. If both burners are indeed affected by excess fire, then White Tiger Decoction is appropriate for both. If there is more thirst than hunger, especially with illness predominantly in the lungs, then Ginseng White Tiger Decoction should be used. If water is deficient in the lower burner and fire is flaming in the upper burner, and there is a need to clear it, then Jade Maiden Decoction or a modified version of One-Yin Decoction should be administered.[86p]

    一云：上焦渴，是心火刑金所致，宜降火清金，以兰香叶、白葵花、黄蘗、知母，少加升麻，以引清气上升而渴自止，此说亦可酌用。　　中消火证，以善饥而瘦，古法直以调胃承气汤及三黄丸之类主之。然既已善饥，其无停积可知。既无停积，则止宜清火，岂堪攻击？非有干结不通等证，而用此二剂，恐非所宜。若其果属胃火，别无虚证，宜三补丸、玉泉散、白虎汤及抽薪饮之类，皆可择而用也。　　下消证，小便淋浊如膏如油，或加烦躁耳焦，此肾水亏竭之证。古法用六味地黄丸之类主之，固其宜矣。然以余观之，则亦当辨其寒热滑濇，分而治之，庶乎尽善。[87p]

    One says: The thirst in the upper burner is caused by the heart fire injuring the metal. It is advisable to lower the fire and clear the metal using ingredients like orchid leaves, white glossy privet flowers, yellow coptis, and anemarrhena, adding a little asarum to guide the clear qi upward and alleviate thirst. This approach can also be appropriately used.

    For the symptom of deficiency fire in the middle burner, characterized by being hungry yet thin, the ancient method directly uses formulas like the Stomach Harmonizing and Qi Regulating Decoction and San Huang Wan. However, since there is already good hunger, there should be no stagnation. If there is no stagnation, it is best to clear the fire; it is not suitable to attack the fire. Without symptoms like clumping and obstruction, using these two formulas may not be appropriate. If it is indeed due to stomach fire with no deficiency symptoms, then formulas like San Bu Wan, Yu Quan San, Bai Hu Tang, and Chou Xin Yin can all be considered for use.

    For the symptom of lower burner deficiency, where the urination is turbid like grease or oil, and there may be additional symptoms of restlessness and buzzing in the ears, this indicates depletion of kidney water. The ancient method uses formulas like Six-Flavor Rehmannia Pill to address this, which is indeed appropriate. However, from my observation, it is also necessary to distinguish between cold and heat, slick and turbid, and to treat them accordingly, so as to achieve the best outcome.[87p]

    若淋浊如膏，兼热病而有火者，宜补而兼清，以加减一阴煎或补阴丸、大补阴丸，或六味地黄丸加黄蘗、知母之类主之。若下消而兼濇者，宜补宜利，以六味地黄丸之类主之。若下焦淋浊而全无火者，乃气不摄精而然，但宜壮水养气，此左归饮、大补元煎之类主之。若火衰不能化气，气虚不能化液者，犹当以右归饮、右归丸、八味地黄丸之类主之。若下焦无火而兼滑者，当以固肾补阴为主，宜秘元煎、固阴煎及芩朮菟丝丸之类主之。　　三消证，古人以上焦属肺，中焦属胃，下焦属肾，而多从火治，是固然矣。然以余论之，则三焦之火，多有病本于肾，而无不由乎命门者。[88p]

    If there is turbid urine like mucus, accompanied by heat and fire, it is advisable to supplement and also clear. One can use a formula such as Yiyin Decotion or Bunyin Pills, Dabu Yinjian, or Liuwei Dihuang Wan with Huangbai and Zhimu. If there is downward leakage and accompanying difficulty in urination, it is necessary to supplement and facilitate, primarily using formulas like Liuwei Dihuang Wan. If there is turbid urine in the lower burner with no fire, it is due to the inability of qi to contain essence, and one should focus on strengthening water and nourishing qi, using formulas like Zuo Gui Yin or Dabu Yuan Jian. If fire diminishes and cannot transform qi, and qi deficiency cannot transform fluids, one should still use formulas like You Gui Yin, You Gui Wan, or Bamei Dihuang Wan. If there is no fire in the lower burner but there is slippage, the main focus should be on consolidating the kidneys and supplementing yin, using formulas like Miyuan Jian, Gu Yin Jian, and Qinzhu Tusi Wan.

    Regarding the three types of excesses, ancients categorized the upper burner with the lungs, the middle burner with the stomach, and the lower burner with the kidneys, often treating primarily with fire, which is indeed appropriate. However, in my view, the fire of the three burner's path often has its disease rooted in the kidneys, and it is invariably related to the vital gate.[88p]

    夫命门为水火之腑，凡水亏证，固能为消为渴，而火亏证，亦能为消为渴者，何也？盖水不济火则火不归原，故有火游于肺而为上消者，有火游于胃而为中消者，有火烁阴精而为下消者，是皆真阴不足，水亏于下之消证也。　　又有阳不化气则水精不布，水不得火则有降无升，所以直入膀胱而饮一溲二，以致泉源不滋，天壤枯涸者，是皆真阳不足，火亏于下之消证也。阴虚之消，治宜壮水，固有言之者矣。阳虚之消，谓宜补火，则人必不信。不知釜底加薪，氤氲彻顶，槁禾得雨，生意归巅，此无他，皆阳气之使然也，亦生杀之微权也。余因消证多虚，难堪剥削，若不求其斫丧之因，而再伐生气，则消者愈消，无从复矣。故再笔于此，用以告夫明者。[89p]

    The Gate of Life is the organ of water and fire. When there is a deficiency of water, it can certainly cause consumption and thirst; similarly, when there is a deficiency of fire, it can also lead to consumption and thirst. Why is this the case? It is because when water fails to support fire, fire cannot return to its source. Therefore, fire may wander to the lungs causing upper consumption, or to the stomach causing middle consumption, or it may consume the essence of yin causing lower consumption. These are all manifestations of true yin deficiency and indicate that water is insufficient, leading to consumption.

    Moreover, when yang fails to transform qi, water essence cannot be distributed. Water without fire cannot rise but only descend, resulting in direct entry into the bladder causing scanty urination, leading to a depletion of the springs and desiccation of the earth. This too is a manifestation of true yang deficiency, indicative of downwards fire deficiency causing consumption.

    For yin deficiency-based consumption, treatment should focus on nourishing water, as has been advised by many. However, when it comes to yang deficiency-induced consumption, people often doubt the need to replenish fire. They do not realize that adding fuel beneath a cauldron enhances the steam, that dried grains gain life from rain, and that growth returns to the peaks—these are all the workings of yang energy and represent subtle balances of life and death.

    Because consumption signs are often due to deficiency and cannot withstand excessive depletion, if one does not seek the root causes of this depletion and continues to drain the vital energy, the consumption will worsen and recovery will be impossible. Therefore, I write this again to inform the discerning.[89p]

    　　　　石室秘箓 【清　陈士铎】

    　　　　　消渴证治

    　　消渴之证，虽分上中下，而肾虚以致渴，则无不同也。故治消渴之法，以治肾为主，不必问其上中下之消也。吾有一方最奇，名合治汤。熟地三两，山茱萸、麦冬各二两，车前子五钱，元参一两，水煎服，日日饮之，三消自愈。此方补肾而加清火之味，似乎有肾火者宜之，不知消证，非火不成也。我补水而少去火，以分清水湿之气，则火从膀胱而出，而真气仍存，所以消证易平也，又何必加桂附之多事哉！惟久消之后，下身寒冷之甚者，本方加肉桂二钱，亦向应异常。倘不遵吾分两，妄意增减，亦速之死而已，安望其有生哉？　　消渴之证，虽有上中下之分，其实皆肾水之不足也。倘用泻火止渴之药，愈消其阴，必至更助其火，有渴甚而死者矣。治法必须补肾中之水，水足而火自消。然而此火，非实火也。实火可以寒消，虚火必须火引。[90p]

    Secrets of the Stone Chamber
    Treatment for Diabetes

    The symptoms of diabetes, although categorized into upper, middle, and lower types, all fundamentally stem from kidney deficiency causing thirst, and there is no difference in this regard. Therefore, the primary method for treating diabetes should focus on nourishing the kidneys, without needing to distinguish between the types. I possess a particularly remarkable formula called "Combined Treatment Decoction." It consists of three taels of cooked Rehmannia, two taels each of Cornelian cherry and Ophiopogon, five qian of Plantago seeds, and one tael of Yuanshen, boiled in water and consumed daily. This will naturally cure the three types of diabetes. This formula nourishes the kidneys while also addressing excess heat. It seems suitable for those with kidney fire, but one must understand that the symptoms of diabetes cannot materialize without a fire element. I replenish water while reducing fire, allowing the excess heat to exit through the bladder while the true energy remains intact, making recovery from diabetes easier. Why complicate matters by adding more herbs like cinnamon? However, for those who have suffered long-term from diabetes and experience extreme cold in the lower body, this formula may include an additional two qian of cinnamon, if such an abnormal condition arises. If one does not follow my proportions and recklessly adjusts the ingredients, it will lead to swift death—how can one hope for survival? The symptoms of diabetes, although classified into upper, middle, and lower categories, ultimately reflect an insufficiency of kidney water. If one uses fire-clearing and thirst-quenching medications, it will further deplete the yin, inevitably augmenting the fire, which could lead to severe thirst and death. The treatment must focus on replenishing the water within the kidneys; sufficient water will naturally extinguish the fire. However, this fire is not real fire; true fire can be extinguished by cold, while虚火 (fictitious fire) must be drawn out by fire itself.[90p]

    又须补肾中之火，火温于命门，下热而上热自除矣。方名引火升阴汤，元参二两，肉桂、北五味各二钱，山茱萸四钱，熟地、麦冬各一两，巴戟天五钱，水煎服。此方大补肾中之水，兼温命门之火，引火归原而火气自消，正不必止渴而渴自除，不必止消而消自愈也。　　大渴之证，必用石膏，往往有一昼夜而用至斤许者。盖热之极，药不得不用之重，此时倘守定不可多与之言，必杀之矣。但此等证，乃万人中一有之，不可执之以治凡有胃火之人也。　　大渴之证，用石膏以平胃火，无人不知矣，尚有未知其故者。胃火飞腾奔越，不啻如火之燎原，必得倾盆之雨，始能滂沛而息灭之。原取其一时权宜之计，故可暂时用之，多能取效。必不可久用，久用则败亡也。尚有一方并传，以为临证之鉴。大渴不止，方用石膏数两，知母三钱，糯米一撮，麦冬三两，人参亦数两，与石膏同用，半夏三钱，甘草一钱，竹叶百片，元参二两，水煎服。[91p]

    One must also replenish the fire in the kidneys, as the fire warms the life gate; when the lower heat is addressed, the upper heat naturally resolves. This prescription is called "Fire-Attracting Yin Decoction," consisting of two taels of Yuan Shen, two qian each of cinnamon and northern five-flavor fruit, four qian of Shan Zhu Yu, one tael each of cooked earth and Mai Dong, five qian of Ba Ji Tian, all decocted in water for consumption. This formula greatly replenishes the water in the kidneys while warming the fire of the life gate, drawing the fire back to its source and allowing the fire energy to dissipate on its own. It is unnecessary to specifically quench thirst; the thirst will resolve itself, and it is not necessary to specifically subside heat; the heat will heal itself.

    For severe thirst, gypsum must be used, often accumulating to a pound over the course of a day and night. When heat is at its extreme, heavy medication is unavoidable. At this time, it is essential to avoid excessive conversation; otherwise, it could be fatal. However, this type of condition is extremely rare, occurring only once in a multitude of cases, and should not be applied indiscriminately to those with general stomach heat.

    For severe thirst, using gypsum to calm stomach heat is widely known, yet some may not understand its reason. When stomach heat surges uncontrollably, it is akin to a fire ravaging the wilderness; it requires a torrential rain to dampen and extinguish it. The use of gypsum is thus a temporary measure, often effective in the short term, but it must not be used long term as it leads to ruin.

    There is also another formula passed down as a clinical reference. For unceasing severe thirst, use several taels of gypsum, three qian of Zhi Mu, a pinched amount of glutinous rice, three taels of Mai Dong, several taels of Ren Shen, to be used alongside gypsum, with three qian of Ban Xia, one qian of Gan Cao, one hundred pieces of bamboo leaves, and two taels of Yuan Shen, all decocted in water for consumption.[91p]

    　　五苓散 【《金匮》，下同】 　治小便不利而渴。　　茯苓　猪苓去皮　白朮各七钱半　桂心半两　泽泻一两二钱七分　　右五味为末，以白饮和服方寸匕，日三服。多饮暖水，汗出愈。

    Fang

    Wuling Powder (from "Jinkui", same below)
    Treats difficulty in urination and thirst.
    Ingredients: Poria, pork poria (peeled), white Atractylodes, each 7.5 grams; cinnamon heart, 25 grams; Alisma, 37.5 grams.
    Powder the five ingredients together and take with a small spoonful mixed in warm water three times a day. Drink plenty of warm water; sweating will facilitate recovery.

    Zhuling Decoction
    Treats fever, thirst, and difficulty in urination.
    Ingredients: Pork poria (peeled), Poria, donkey-hide gelatin, talc, Alisma, each 37.5 grams.
    For the five ingredients, use 4 liters of water, first boil four of the ingredients for a while, then take 2 liters, strain out the residue, and dissolve the gelatin in it. Take this warm in 1.25 liters three times a day.[92p]

    　　文蛤散　治渴欲饮水不止。
    　　文蛤四两
    　　杵为散，以沸汤五合，和服方寸匕。

    Wenhe Powder - Treats thirst for water that cannot be quenched.

    • Wenhe: 4 taels.
      Pound it into a powder, use 5 cups of boiling water, then mix and take a spoonful.

    Ginseng and Gypsum Decoction (Hejian) - Treats obstructive heat in the upper jiao, thirst with little appetite.

    • Ginseng: 5 qian; Gypsum: 1 tael; Anemarrhena: 7 qian; Licorice: 4 qian.
      Take 5 qian each time, decoct in water, and take warm after meals. "Liangfang" includes Scutellaria and Almonds.

    Jiajian Dili Pio Powder (Qian Family) - Treats upper consumption.

    • Anemarrhena, Chaihu, Fried Licorice, Banxia, Dili Pi, Astragalus, Red Poria, White Peony, Gypsum, Scutellaria, Platycodon, all equal parts.
      Mix into a fine powder, take 3 qian each time, with 5 slices of ginger, decoct in water, and take warm away from meals.

    Bamboo Leaf Gypsum Decoction (Zhongjing) - Treats thirst.

    • Gypsum: 1 jin; Schisandra (remove seeds): 1 sheng; Banxia: 0.5 sheng, wash in broth; Japonica rice: 0.5 sheng; Licorice: 2 taels, fried; Ginseng: 3 taels; Bamboo leaves: 2 handfuls.
      Combine these seven ingredients with 10 dou of water, boil until 6 sheng remains, remove residues, add Japonica rice and cook until the rice is done, then remove the rice. Take 1 sheng warm three times a day.

    Bamboo Leaf Astragalus Decoction - Treats qi and blood deficiency with excessive stomach fire causing thirst.

    • Fresh bamboo leaves, Sheng dihuang, each: 2 qian; Astragalus, Motherwort, Dong Quai, Chuan Xiong, fried Scutellaria, Licorice, Peony, Ginseng, Banxia, Gypsum (calcined), each: 1 qian.
      Combine and decoct in water to take.[93p]

    Huangqi Decoction: Treats the condition where cold from the heart moves to the lungs, causing lung consumption, with less drinking and more urination. It aims to nourish the lungs and stabilize the heart. Ingredients include three taels of Huangqi, each two taels of five-flavored herb, ginseng, mulberry bark, and ophiopogon, and one and a half taels each of goji berries and cooked rehmannia. Crush the ingredients; each dose is five qian, boiled in two cups of water until one cup remains. Drink warm without specific timing.

    Mai Men Dong Drink: Treats the condition where heat from the heart moves to the lungs, causing diaphragm consumption, chest fullness, heart distress, and diminished spirit. Ingredients include equal parts of ginseng, poria, ophiopogon, five-flavored herb, fresh rehmannia, anemarrhena, honey-fried licorice, and kudzu root. Crush the ingredients; each dose is five qian, add fourteen bamboo leaves, and boil until reduced to seven parts. Drink warm without specific timing.

    Mai Men Dong Drink for Aging: Treats extreme thirst in the elderly and weak. Ingredients include seven and a half qian each of ginseng, goji berries, white poria, and licorice, and half a tael each of five-flavored herb and ophiopogon. Prepare with ginger water for consumption. One version includes earth bone peel, omitting goji berries.

    Modified Three Huang Pills: Treats toxicity from cinnabar and heat-induced thirst, to be used with discernment for serious cases. Ingredients include four taels of Huangqin in spring, six taels in summer and autumn, three taels in winter; three taels of da huang in spring, one tael in summer, two taels in autumn, four taels in winter; four taels of Huanglian in spring, seven taels in summer, three taels in autumn, two taels in winter. Grind to a fine powder, mix with honey to form pills the size of a nut. Each dose is ten pills, taken for one month for recovery.[94p]

    　　猪肚丸 【《三因方》】 　治强中消渴。　　黄连　粟米　(艹舌)蒌根　茯神各四两　知母　麦门冬各二两　　右为细末，将大猪肚一个，洗净入药末于内，以麻线缝合口，置甑中炊极烂，取出，药别研，以猪肚为膏，再入炼蜜，搜和前药杵匀，丸如梧子大。每服五十丸，参汤下。又方加人参、熟地黄、干葛。又方除知母、粟米，用小麦。

    Pig Stomach Balls (from "San Yin Fang")
    For treating excessive thirst from yang deficiency.
    4 ounces each of: Huanglian, millet, (Cao She) Lou root, Fuzhen;
    2 ounces each of: Zhimu, Mai Men Dong.
    Grind the above into a fine powder, take a large pig stomach, clean it, and fill it with the powdered medicine, sewing the opening with hemp thread. Place it in a steamer and cook until very tender. Remove it, separately grind the medicine again, turn it into a paste with the pig stomach, and mix with refined honey, then pound evenly into balls the size of a walnut. Take fifty balls with ginseng soup. Alternatively, you can add ginseng, cooked Rehmannia, and dried Kudzu. Another variation excludes Zhimu and millet, using wheat instead.

    Transforming Water Elixir
    For treating persistent thirst and pain in the hands and feet, or heart pain; "Ben Shi" addresses excessive intake of cold water.
    Use 4 pieces of large Chuanwu, remove the skin and decoct;
    6 ounces of thick clam powder, prepare;
    1 ounce of roasted licorice;
    3 ounces of fresh oyster.
    Grind the above into a fine powder, and use vinegar to moisten and form into pills. Take fifteen pills with freshly drawn water. For heart pain, take with vinegar soup for immediate relief. For those drinking a stone of water, one dose cures. Hai Zang states: the medicine can transform stagnant water.

    Celestial Method to Reduce Water
    Also called Slashing Dragon Executioner. Treats excessive thirst caused by yang deficiency in the three burners and an insatiable thirst.
    1 ounce each of: Ginseng, flower pollen, Zhimu, Huanglian, bitter cucumber, Mai Men Dong, floating duckweed, white broad beans, Huangqi, plus a little yellow lead.
    Grind into a fine powder and take ten grams, mixing with freshly drawn water to consume.[95p]

    Sweet Dew Drink

    This treats thirst and digestion issues, alleviating extreme thirst and lack of control over drinking water. Symptoms include numbness in upper and lower teeth, a stiff and swollen painful tongue, loss of appetite, abdominal distention and pain, yellowing of the complexion, yellowing of the eyes, and in severe cases, weakness of the limbs, pallor of the face, acute pain beneath the ribs, frequent sneezing and anger, forgetfulness, and pain in the buttocks, waist, and back.

    Ingredients:

    • 2.5 qian of gypsum
    • 3 qian of platycodon root
    • 2 qian each of ginseng, turmeric, cimicifuga, and licorice (roasted)
    • 2 qian each of gardenia fruit and anemarrhena
    • 1 qian each of cardamom, angelica, and forsythia, as well as raw licorice and pepper
    • 0.5 qian each of coptis, white hibiscus flower, and orchid
    • 0.3 qian each of berberine (stir-fried) and peeled apricot kernels, nutmeg, and bupleurum
    • 0.2 qian of agastache
    • 1.5 qian of ophiopogon root
    • 1 whole scorpion (detoxified)

    These ingredients are ground into a powder, soaked in broth, and mixed with steamed dough to form pills, which are then dried in the sun and crushed into pieces the size of yellow millet. Each dose is 2 qian, taken in the palm and licked with the tongue before swallowing with some broth, or a little plain soup may also be used. This method is gentle, preventing not only fullness but also preventing the spread of sores and ailments.

    Another formula includes 1.2 liang of gypsum and 1 qian each of turmeric and gardenia fruit.[96p]

    Huanglian Ointment
    Indications are the same as before.
    One pound of Huanglian, finely ground into powder; one pound each of cow milk, white lotus root juice, and fresh Rehmannia juice. Boil the juices together to create an ointment, roll the Huanglian powder into small round pills the size of mung beans. Take twenty pills per dose, swallow with a sip of broth, up to ten doses a day.

    Sheng Di Huang Ointment
    Indications are the same as before.
    One bowl-sized handful of fresh Rehmannia, one bowl of winter honey, one tael of white Poria, half a tael of ginseng. First, wash and crush the Rehmannia, using fresh spring water to dissolve it. Boil with honey until reduced by half, then mix in the powdered ginseng and Poria, storing in a tightly sealed ceramic container. Take with a spoon.

    Shunli Powder
    Used for internal heat in the stomach with ability to eat; scant reddish-yellow urine and slight benefit with no appetite as an effect; do not take excessively.
    One tael each of Houpu and Zhishi, four taels of prepared Da Huang.
    Each dose is five qian, prepared by boiling in water and taken away from meals.

    Shen Pu Pill
    Used for food retention in the stomach, dispelling internal heat, promoting appetite without generating flesh.
    One tael each of ginseng, red Poria, stone calamus, flying Zi, earth bone peel, and cow knee soaked in wine.
    Grind into powder, mix with honey to form pills, taking twenty pills per dose with rice wine.[97p]

    Luminous Gold Pill: Treats heat-induced thirst and stops aftereffects, replenishes essence and blood, benefits various deficiencies, alleviates fatigue, reduces heat in joints, calms the mind and strengthens will, stabilizes the spirit and soul, reinforces the organs, promotes food intake, and prevents sores.

    Ingredients:

    • 1 large pig's stomach
    • 3 taels of Coptis
    • 2 taels of fresh ginger, ground
    • 2 taels of white honey

    Preparation:
    First, clean the pig's stomach thoroughly, then stuff it with scallions, pepper, vinegar, and the aforementioned ingredients. Add water and rice wine into a silver or stone container and boil for half a day. Strain out the Coptis and wash away the honey and wine completely, grinding it into a fine powder. Next, mix with water to form a paste and fill the pig's stomach, sewing it shut. Place it again in the silver or stone container and boil until soft, then grind into a paste.

    Additional ingredients:

    • 2 taels of ginseng
    • 2 taels of Schisandra
    • 2 taels of peeled eucommia, stir-fried with ginger juice, and strands removed
    • 2 taels of Chinese yam
    • 2 taels of Dendrobium
    • 2 taels of cornelian cherry, pitted
    • 1 tael of Plantago seeds
    • 2 taels of fresh lotus flesh, peeled
    • 2 taels of tortoise shell, vinegar-baked
    • 2 taels of cooked Rehmannia
    • 2 taels of Angelica sinensis
    • 1 tael of magnetite, calcined
    • 1 tael of white poria
    • 1 tael of fried Sophora fruit
    • 1 tael of Chuanxiong
    • 4 taels of Astragalus
    • 5 taels of Cuscuta, soaked in wine, steamed, and ground
    • 1 qian of musk, ground separately
    • ½ tael of agarwood

    The above ingredients should be ground into a fine powder, then mixed with the pig's stomach paste. If needed, add a bit more cooked honey, and pound several thousand times until the mixture forms pills the size of a walnut. Take fifty pills each time, with warm wine or glutinous rice drink before meals. Another variation includes 2 taels of Atractylodes and 1 tael of yangqi stone.[99p]

    Tianmen Dong Pill treats early symptoms of internal heat, feelings of hunger after eating, hands and feet feeling hot, back pain and discomfort, and cloudy urine.

    • Bitter Wormwood (1 tael)

    Grind the above into a fine powder, then form into pills the size of a walnut using honey. Take twenty pills with millet drink before meals.[100p]

    　　猪肾荠苨汤　治消中，日饮水八九升者。　　猪肾一具　大豆一升　荠苨　石膏各三两　人参　茯苓　知母　葛根　黄芩　磁石绵裹　(艹舌)蒌根　甘草各二两　　右(口父)咀，用水一斗五升，先煮猪肾大豆，取一斗，去滓下药，煮取三升，分作三服，渴急饮之。下焦热者，夜辄服一剂，渴止勿服。一方茯苓作茯神。
    　　肾沥散　治消肾，肾气虚损发渴，小便数，腰膝痛。　　鸡(月坒)胵微炙　远志　人参　桑螵蛸炒　黄芪　泽泻　熟地　茯苓　龙骨　桂　当归各一两　麦门冬　川芎各二两　五味子　炙甘草　元参名半两　磁石三两，研碎，水淘去赤汁　　右銼碎，每服用羊肾一对，切去脂膜，先以水一盏半，煮肾至一盏，去水上浮脂及肾，次入药五钱，生姜半分，煎至五分，去滓，空心服。晚食前再服。[101p]

    Pig Kidney and Herbs Decoction: Treats consumption with excessive thirst, drinking eight to nine liters of water daily.

    Ingredients: One whole pig kidney, one sheng of soybeans, three liang each of ephedra and gypsum, two liang each of ginseng, poria, anemarrhena, kudzu root, scutellaria, and magnetite wrapped in cotton, as well as two liang each of wild loofah root and licorice.

    Preparation: Grind the ingredients, use 15 liters of water, first boil the pig kidney and soybeans, take out 10 liters, remove residue, add the other ingredients, and boil down to three liters. Divide into three doses for urgent thirst. For heat signs in the lower abdomen, take one dose at night and refrain from further doses once thirst is relieved. In some recipes, poria may be substituted with fu shen.

    Kidney Drain Powder: Treats kidney consumption, with symptoms of kidney qi deficiency, thirst, frequent urination, and pain in the lower back and knees.

    Ingredients: Slightly roasted chicken kidney, distant wisdom herb, ginseng, stir-fried silk worm, astragalus, alisma, cooked rehmannia, poria, dragon bone, cinnamon, and angelica, each one liang; two liang each of oshun pitcher and chuanxiong; five coins of schisandra; roasted licorice; half a liang of original ginseng and three liang of magnetite, crushed and washed to remove red juice.

    Preparation: For each dose, use one pair of sheep kidneys, removing the fat membrane. First, boil the kidneys in one and a half bowls of water until reduced to one bowl, removing floating fat and kidneys. Next, add five qian of the herbs and half a fen of fresh ginger, and simmer until reduced to half a bowl. Strain and take on an empty stomach. Repeat before dinner.[101p]

    　　金银箔丸　治消肾口干，眼濇阴痿，手足烦疼，小便多。　　金箔　银箔各一百片，俱细研　丹砂细研　(艹舌)蒌根各二两　巴戟去心　山药　五味子　泽泻各一两半　肉苁蓉酒浸一宿切，焙干　天冬各二两半　黄连四两　白茯苓　生地焙　葛根各三两　麦冬焙三两半　　右除别研药外为细未，再研匀，炼蜜和丸如梧桐子大。每服二十丸，加至三十丸，不拘时，粟米饮送下。

    Golden and Silver Foil Pill: Treats kidney issues with dry mouth, dry eyes, impotence, discomfort in limbs, and frequent urination. Take 100 pieces each of gold foil and silver foil, finely ground. Grind 2 taels each of realgar and (wild) yam root, and 1.5 taels each of Ba Jiao (a type of herb), five-flavored fruit, and Ze Xie. Then, process 2.5 taels each of Mu Tong (another herb) and dried Rehmannia root, and 3 taels each of dried lotus seeds and dried chicken’s gizzard. Exclude other powdered herbs to achieve a fine consistency, then mix with honey and form pills the size of a catalpa seed. Take 20 to 30 pills at any time, swallowed with millet drink.

    White Poria Pill: Treats kidney disorders stemming from post-digestive issues, where stomach heat enters the kidneys, consuming kidney vitality and causing dryness, leading to this ailment with increasingly thin legs and weakness in the waist and feet. Use 1 tael each of white poria, raspberry, coptis, pollen, dioscorea, ginseng, cooked rehmannia, and original ginseng; 7.5 qian each of dendrobium and cyperus rotundus; and 30 fried chicken intestines. Grind into a fine powder, mix with honey, and pound into pills the size of a catalpa seed. Take 30 pills under the tongue before meals with a decoction of magnetite.[102p]

    Modified Eight Flavor Pill treats kidney water deficiency, inability to nourish upwards, heart fire rising, inability to balance, restlessness and thirst, frequent urination, white discharge, impotence, reduced appetite, thinning skin, or swollen legs with thin, small feet.

    　　忍冬丸　治渴疾愈，须预防发痈疽。　　忍冬草不以多少，根茎花叶皆可用之，一名老公须，一名蜜啜花，一名金银花，一名左缠藤，水洗净用　　右用米曲酒于瓶内浸，以糠火煨一宿，取出晒干，入甘草少许为末，即以所浸酒煮糊为丸如梧桐子大。每服五十丸至百丸，酒饮任下。一方用忍冬草煎服。此藤凌冬不雕，三月开花五出，黄白相间，微香，蒂带红。《外科精要》又以酒煮窨服，取时不犯铁气，服至大小肠通利，此药到得力。用干者，不及生者效速。仍治五种飞尸。酒研敷疮亦好，但留一口泄毒气，真经效奇药也。此药不特治痈，亦能止渴，并五痔诸漏。

    Honeysuckle Pills: Treats thirst and sickness but should be used to prevent boils and abscesses. Honeysuckle can be used regardless of quantity; roots, stems, flowers, and leaves are all applicable. It is also known as old husband’s need, honey suckle flower, gold and silver flower, or left vine. After washing the plant, use rice malt wine to soak it in a bottle, then steam over husk fire for a night, take it out to dry, and ground with a little licorice into powder. Form into pills the size of a catalpa seed using the soaked wine boiled into a paste. Take fifty to a hundred pills, and drink wine as desired. Another method is to decoct honeysuckle for consumption. This vine braves winter without wilting, flowers in March with yellow and white intermingled, slightly fragrant, with red-tipped stalks. According to the "Essentials of Surgery," it should also be prepared with wine and taken cautiously to avoid iron flavor, as it aids in smooth passage through the intestines. This medicine is effective. Using dried honeysuckle is slower than fresh. It also treats five types of flying corpse. Wine-grounded application for wounds is beneficial, but leave an opening to release toxic gas, as it is truly a miraculous medicine. This remedy not only treats boils but can also quench thirst and alleviate five types of hemorrhoids.

Grind the ingredients and take four qian with a mug of water, decocting until one-third remains, strain, and consume warm at any time.[104p]

    Mei Su Wan: Treats thirst caused by heat in the diaphragm and irritability, generating body fluids. Ingredients: 250 grams each of white plum flesh, Su leaves, and black plum flesh; 450 grams of various herbs decocted; 52.5 grams of peeled Ophiopogon; 15 grams each of myrrh and ginseng; 75 grams of roasted licorice. Grind the ingredients into a fine powder, mix with yellow wax juice to form pills the size of a chicken’s head. Take one pill whenever needed, dissolve in the mouth and swallow saliva. Useful for quenching thirst while walking.

    Ku Lian Decoction (from "Yijian Zhi"): Treats thirst caused by parasites. Ingredients: a handful of fresh white bark from the bitter neem root, cut and roasted; a small amount of musk. Combine with two bowls of water, decoct until reduced to one bowl, and drink on an empty stomach. Even if exhausted, it won’t matter. Afterward, pass three to four parasites resembling red roundworms, and the thirst will cease. Thus, it is known that thirst can be caused by parasites consuming the body’s fluids.

    Zhu Ji Decoction (from "San Yin Fang"): Treats the three types of thirst. Ingredients: a piece of pig spine bone measuring about 12 inches; 49 jujubes; 3 grams of cardamom; 49 lily seeds; and 225 grams of roasted licorice. Combine with five bowls of water, decoct to extract the juice, and drink when thirsty.

    Shui She Wan (from "Sheng Hui Fang"): Treats thirst, heat in the limbs, dry mouth, and heart agitation. Ingredients: one live water snake, skinned and roasted to a powder; finely powdered tian huafen; a pinch of musk; 50 snails, soaked in water for five days to collect saliva. Mix with millet porridge to form pills the size of mung beans. Take ten pills with ginger soup.[107p]

    Shengjin Ganlu Decoction, also known as Qingliang Yinzi. It treats wasting and thirsting syndrome with weight loss, dry stools, and frequent urination.

    Ingredients:

    • Gypsum, Gentian Grass, and Coptis; each 3 grams
    • Chaihu, Qianghuo, and prepared Astragalus; each 6 grams
    • Wine Motherwort, Wine Scutellaria, and honey-fried Licorice; each 5 grams
    • Dang Gui (Angelica) 4.5 grams
    • Shengma 1.5 grams
    • Fangfeng, Fangji, Shengdi, Licorice; each 1 gram
    • 10 Apricot Kernels
    • 5 Peach Kernels
    • A pinch of Safflower

    Combine the above ingredients, take with 2 cups of water, simmer until only 1 cup remains, then add a spoonful of wine, warm and take as needed.

    Ren Shen Sanzi for treating wasting and thirsting syndrome.

    Ingredients:

    • Talcum Powder 100 grams
    • Cold Water Stone and Licorice; each 37.5 grams
    • Gypsum 18.75 grams
    • Ginseng 7.5 grams

    Grind into a powder, take 6 grams with warm water.

    Huanglian Pig Stomach Pill for treating wasting and thirsting syndrome, also addresses vigorous thirst.

    Ingredients:

    • One male pig stomach
    • Huang Lian (Coptis) 250 grams
    • Ophiopogon, Motherwort, and (Cơ/舌) Lou root; each 150 grams

    Grind the four ingredients into a powder, fill inside the pig stomach, seal with string, steam until soft, then pound in a stone mortar. Add a small amount of honey, roll into balls the size of walnuts. Consume with rice beverage, 100 pills. According to "Qian Jin", also use 250 grams of glutinous rice, 150 grams each of (Cơ/舌) Lou and Poria, 100 grams of Motherwort, and 75 grams of Ophiopogon, pig stomach and Coptis together.[109p]

    Lotus Root Juice Paste [Danxi]
    Used to treat stomach heat and internal consumption.
    Ingredients: White lotus root juice, raw rehmannia juice, cow's milk, yellow comminuted bitter herb, ginger juice, powdered marshmallow root.
    Mix the above juices with the two powders, then add white honey to create a paste. Take with a spoon, slowly place it on the tongue, and wash down with white broth, three to four times a day.

    Guanqimen Prescription

    Ginseng and Poria Powder [Dongyuan]
    Also known as Ginseng Powder. Treats kidney deficiency with cloudy urine resembling paste.
    Ingredients: Talcum powder, cold water stone, each 1.5 qian; licorice 0.7 qian; red poria, dried kudzu root, yellow scutellaria, peppermint, rhubarb, each 0.5 qian; forsythia 0.3 qian; ginseng, white atractylodes, zephyranthes, platycodon, gardenia, marshmallow powder, and sand bitters, each 0.2 qian.
    Grind the above into a powder and prepare as a decoction for oral administration.

    Modified Kidney Qi Pills [Danxi, same hereafter]
    Used to treat kidney deficiency, dry mouth, and thirst, with thin and emaciated legs.
    Ingredients: Cooked rehmannia 2 liang; cinnabar peony, white poria, cornelian cherry, zephyranthes, five-flavored fruit, deer antler, and Chinese yam, each 1 liang; cinnamon and aromatic sandalwood, each 0.5 liang.
    Grind into powder and make into pills the size of a walnut. Take 70 to 80 pills with warm salt water.[110p]

    Shen Bu Di Huang Wan: Treats kidney deficiency and diabetes. It can reduce heart fire, benefit kidney water, stop thirst, and clarify vision.

    1. One pound of Huangbok, shredded.
    2. Half a pound of Shengdi, soaked in wine for two days, then steamed and ground into a paste, mixed with Huangbok and dried.
    3. Four taels of Bai Fuling, two taels each of Shudi, Tiandong, Ren Shen, and Ganju.
    4. One tael each of Quing, fried in wine, Danggui, Zhihua, and Maidong.

    The above are ground into a powder, formed into pills the size of grapes. Take them on an empty stomach with salt and wine, about seventy to eighty pills.

    Lu Rong Wan: Treats kidney deficiency and diabetes, with excessive urination.

    1. Two taels of Maidong.
    2. Seven and a half qian of deer antler, Shudi, Huangqi, Wuweizi, and poultry bile (fried).
    3. Seven and a half qian each of Rou Congrong (soaked in wine), Shanzhuyu, and Poyao (fried).
    4. Seven and a half qian of Niuxi (soaked in wine) and Ren Shen.
    5. Five qian each of Bai Fuling, Digupi, and Yuanshen.

    The above are ground into a powder, made into honey pills the size of grapes. Take them on an empty stomach with rice drink, about fifty to seventy pills. Liang Fang does not include Yuanshen.

    Zi Yin Yang Rong Tang: Treats diabetes with loss of bodily fluids, dry mouth, and throat.

    1. One and a half qian each of Ren Shen and Shengdi.
    2. One qian each of Danggui, Maidong, Bai Shaoyao, and Zhimu (fried in honey).
    3. One qian of Huangbok (fried in honey), five fen of licorice, and fifteen grains of Wuweizi.

    Grind the above to make a decoction, and take it.[111p]

    Huanglian Dihuang Decoction (from "Huichun")
    For treating the Three Abnormal Thirsts.
    Ingredients: Huanglian, Shengdi Huang, Huafen, Wuweizi, Donggui, Renshen, Gande, Bai Fuling, Maidong, and Licorice, each one qian. Grind and make into a paste, add two slices of ginger, one date, and ten pieces of bamboo leaves, decoct together to take.

    Yuan Tusi Dan (from "Dexiaofang")
    A divine medicine for treating the Three Thirsts, prevents spermatorrhea, stops seminal fluid, and promotes longevity.
    Ingredients: Tusi Zi, ten liang, soaked in alcohol; Wuweizi, seven liang; Bai Fuling, Lianzi Rou, and Shanyao, each three liang. Grind these into a powder, separately grind three liang of Shanyao into powder, boil the alcohol-soaked Tusi Zi until thick, mix together and form pills the size of a walnut. Take five to seventy pills with rice drink. Pills made with honey are also good. According to "Liangfang," use five liang of Fuling without Shanyao, called Fuling Tusi Wan, for the same indications.[112p]

    Five Juice Jade Spring Pills (from Return to Spring)
    For treating thirst.
    Ingredients:
    Huanglian (Coptis chinensis), dried kudzu root, pollen, Zhimu (anemarrhena), Mai men dong (ophiopogon), Wuweizi (schisandra), ginseng, fresh root of Rehmannia, dried plum flesh, lotus seeds (removed heart), Danggui (angelica), and licorice, each one tael.
    Grind these into a powder. Separately, take human milk, cow milk, or sugarcane juice; if unavailable, use sand sugar, pear juice, or lotus root juice. First, mix these juices with one and a half pounds of honey and boil into a thin paste. Then, combine the powdered herbs with the paste and boil until it bubbles five to seven times. Take five teaspoons, mix with rice drink, two or three times a day. Avoid pungent and hot foods.

    Lychee Paste (from Classified Compendium)
    Stops thirst and generates body fluids.
    Ingredients:
    Lactose (twenty-six taels), clear honey (fourteen taels), dried plum flesh (eight taels), and ginger (five taels, juiced), musk (five fen).
    First, take the clear honey and dried plum flesh, add one and a half dou of water, boil down to half, and filter out the residue. Add the lactose and continue boiling until the sugar melts. Then mix in the musk uniformly. Take one large spoonful, dilute with fresh water, two or three times a day.[113p]

    　　卫生天花丸　歌曰：消渴消中消肾病，三焦五脏生虚热。惟有膀胱冷如冰，意中饮水无休歇。小便昼夜不流通，骨冷皮焦心肺裂。本因饮酒炙煿多，酒余色欲劳无节。饮水吃食日加增，肌肉精髓转枯竭。漩甜如蜜滑如油，口苦咽干舌如血。三消病状最为危，有此仙方真妙诀。　　黄连童便浸三日，晒干，三两　白扁豆炒，二两　芦荟七钱半　辰砂　白茯苓　牡蛎粉　知母　苦参　铁粉　花粉各五钱金银箔各二十片　　右为末，生(艹舌)蒌根汁和生蜜为丸梧子大。麦门冬汤下三五十丸。

    The Magic Pill for Thirst: It is said: "To alleviate thirst, soothe the kidney ailments; the three burners and five organs give rise to internal heat. Only the bladder remains cold like ice, constantly craving water without respite. Urination day and night is obstructed, bones turn cold, skin is burnt, and the heart and lungs crack. This is due to excessive drinking and indulgence, leading to unrestrained desires. Water intake and food consumption increase daily, muscles and essence begin to wither. Sweet as honey and smooth as oil, the mouth is bitter, the throat dry, and the tongue like blood. The symptoms of this 'Three Thirsts' disease are critical; this immortal formula is truly wonderful."

    Ingredients: Soak Coptis chinensis in child's urine for three days, then dry. Three ounces of fried white hyacinth bean, two ounces of aloe vera, seven and a half taels of cinnabar, and five taels each of white poria, oyster shell powder, anemarrhena, bitter gentian, iron powder, and pollen. Twenty pieces of gold and silver foil. Grind these together, mix the root juice of belamcanda and raw honey to form pills the size of walnuts. Take three to fifty pills daily with Mai Men Dong decoction.

    For Treating Thirst: This formula clears the heat of the stomach and intestines. The ingredients: Mai Men Dong, poria, Coptis chinensis, gypsum, and hyacinth each eight parts; ginseng, gentian, and Scutellaria baicalensis each six parts; bulbus fritillariae four parts; bitter orange five parts; shredded ginger, goji berries, and belamcanda root each ten parts. Grind these thirteen ingredients, form pills the size of walnuts. Take ten pills with the juice of millet and rhizome, twice a day. In the "External Manual," where goji berries aren't available, use earth-bone peel instead. When thirsty, drink the following formula: Cut one liter of rhizome and mix with three cups of millet.[114p]

    Take the two ingredients with six liters of water, boil to cook the rice, and then add the previous medicine.

    Another formula for the same condition:

    Polygala root, fresh ginger, fresh Ophiopogon juice, and reed root, each two liters; cut rhizome of rice, three liters. The five ingredients should be crushed, then add one liter of water, boil to obtain three liters, and take in three doses.

    Another formula for the same condition:

    Polygala root, Ophiopogon, lead powder, each eight parts; Poria and licorice, each six parts. The five ingredients should be prepared by filtration, take with a spoonful of gruel, three times a day. (Note: "Poria" is not included in "Wai Tai.")

    Another formula for the same condition:

    Astragalus, Poria, Polygala root, licorice, and Ophiopogon, each three taels; dried rehmannia, five taels. The six ingredients should be crushed, add eight liters of water, boil down to two and a half liters, strain, divide into three doses, and take one dose daily for ten days for best results.

    Another formula for treating thirst for someone who drinks one stone of water daily:

    Two taels of Aconitum, Pueraria, Polygala root, and lead powder, each three taels. The four ingredients should be made into pills the size of a walnut. Take ten pills, three times a day. If thirsty, take them. Reduce Aconitum in spring and summer.

    Huanglian pills for thirst.[115p]

    　　黄连　生地黄各一斤
    　　右二味，绞地黄取汁，浸黄连，出曝燥，复内汁中，令汁尽干，捣末蜜丸梧子大。服二十丸，日三，食前后无拘。亦可为散，以酒服方寸匕。张文仲：地黄作十斤。

    　　鈆丹散　一名胡粉散。治消渴，止小便数，兼消中。　　鉛丹　胡粉　甘草　泽泻　石膏　(艹舌)蒌根　白石脂　赤石脂各五分　　右八味，治下筛，水服方寸匕，日三。壮人一匕半。一年病者一日愈，二年病者二日愈。渴甚者夜二服，腹痛者减之。丸服亦佳，每服十丸。伤多令人腹痛。《肘后》白石脂作贝母。

    Huanglian and Shengdihuang, each one pound.

    For the two ingredients, extract the juice from Shengdihuang, soak Huanglian in it, dry it in the sun, then place it back in the juice until it is completely dried. Grind into powder and form into pills the size of walnuts. Take twenty pills, three times daily, without restrictions before or after meals. It can also be made into a powder, taken with a spoonful of wine. Zhang Wenzhong: use ten pounds of Shengdihuang.

    Gouqi Soup treats thirst and is beneficial.

    Gouqi leaves and branches, one pound; Huanglian, (Caoshai) Luogen, Sheng Gancao, and Shigao, each three taels. The five ingredients should be chewed, boiled in one dou of water to yield three sheng. Divide into five doses, taken three times during the day and twice at night. For severe cases, take more; drink whenever thirsty.

    Qindansan, also known as Hufen San, treats thirst, reduces urination frequency, and alleviates digestion issues.

    Lead dan, Hufen, Gan Cao, Ze Xie, Shigao, (Caoshai) Luogen, Bai Shizhi, and Chi Shizhi, each five fen. The eight ingredients are treated through a sieve, take with a spoonful of water, three times daily. For strong individuals, one and a half spoonfuls. Those with one-year illnesses recover in one day; those with two-year illnesses recover in two days. For severe thirst, take twice at night; reduce dosage for abdominal pain. Pills can also be effective; take ten pills at a time. Excessive use may cause abdominal pain. According to "Zhou Hou," Bai Shizhi can be replaced with Bei Mu.

    Shenbai San, also known as Liu Yi San or Tian Shui San, treats true yin deficiency due to prolonged use of harsh medications or excessive desire for roasted, salty foods, resulting in thirst.

    Gui Fu Hua Shi, six liang; Gan Cao, one liang, used raw.[116p]

    　　右为细末，每服三钱，温水调下。或大渴欲饮冷者，新汲水尤妙。
